reviewText: This game is beyond reproach. Everything from the opening minutes of the cutscenes to the final minutes of the soundtrack are perfectly polished. Every punch and kick thrown in combat is choreographed flawlessly and the sounds and sights of Arkham City create an impressive world for Batman to survey and protect from itself. The story takes so many twists and turns and even if you think you'll know who the next villain is going to be, you're going to have no idea what you're getting yourself into. Batman's got to use every tool at his disposal not just to survive, but to learn the secrets of Arkham City and stop the dangerous path that awaits Gotham's mega-prison on this fateful night.\n\nYou can look at other reviews, they'll describe technically better what you can expect out of this game. But if you really think you're up for the challenge of being Batman during one of his darkest nights, fighting one of his most climactic fights, pick up this game now. It's time to don the cowl, for better or worse.

reviewText:
One of my all time favorite games. Batman: Arkham City took what Arkham Asylum did good and made it a whole lot better. The one thing that Arkham City does the best is that it makes you feel like you're Batman. It does so in a variety of ways, from giving you a large arsenal of gadgets to use, making the combat feel fluid and responsive with lots of different types of attacks, having you investigate crimes by searching for clues and trying to repiece the moments in your head, and best of all, it lets you glide around the city with your wings. There's no question why this is considered one of the best licensed games next to Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic and The Chronicles of Riddick: Assault on Dark Athena.

The GOTY edition really does add to the game. It comes with a few extra challenge maps that are actually fun to play. They certainly are challenging and aren't just tacky add-ons to make the game longer. In fact, the main story is longer than most of todays games, coming in at around 15 hours, not including the side missions (I owned the GFWL version before the Steam version, and I have yet to complete it on Steam). With the side missions, I'd say total gameplay hours would be around 30 hours, since there are tons of extra stuff to do, not including challenge mode.

So overall, this game is worth your time. Even if you aren't a Batman fan or don't know much about his character or the world, this game is fun for everyone who enjoys third person action games.

My only complaint is that the open world can feel dead at times, with no one in the streets and nothing happening, and also how it takes a long time to travel from one area to another if you didn't unlock it already. Arkham Knight will fix this with being able to freely drive the Batmobile.

My personal rating: 9/10 -  Gripping story, fluid combat, awesome graphics, and just downright fun to play.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Great game, well worth the price for the hours of entertainment you will get out of it.

The crazy number of Riddler challenges seems daunting at first but it was actually quite fun colecting them all and the H2H combat is much improved over Batman:AA.

When this game was announced I wondered how could they improve on such an epic game, I was not dissapointed. Pays good lip service to the comics and contains the best voice over cast ever to do the Batman franchise, Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil in my mind are the best Batman and Joker combination ever concieved and they both delievered yet again.

The gadgetry is well thought out and a nice improvement over Batman:AA

The catwoman gameplay felt a little tacked on, especially the bonus missions, it just felt like they couldn't think of anything else to do with her.

The revenge of Harley was actually a nice DLC add on that was a pretty good couple of hours, well worth the original price, and gives you a nice hands on with Robin. Robin definitely feels inferior to Batman in H2H which just adds to the greatness of Batman himself.

Graphically the game is real nice running on the newet iteration of the unreal engine but nothing really ground breaking. Does the job and no real complaints, I just wish they would ditch Phys-X for something else.

Sound wise the game is absolutely great, the atmosphere is fantastic and the sound track is fitting as always.

Rocksteady has made a real masterpiece here and it is a great shame they have been denied the opportunity to do another sequel. I have played through both Batman AA and AC multiple times and enjoyed every moment of every play through.

reviewText:
I have to say I'm not really fond of Batman, I could see the cartoon on TV but I wasn't interested by it.
I started to play and the story gets you right into it like the first (Arkham Asylum), you just can't stop playing until you see the ending scene. This game is just a masterpiece, everything is made up for every batman fan and to make you become one.
You can probably see all the characters in this, the story doesn't really follows the previous one in my opinion, maybe only with The Joker.

When I was complaining of the lack of combat moves in Arkham Asylum, they added more here to create more techniques to make battles like so EPIC.
However, they kept the challenges, they added even more with the Robin, Catwoman and Nightwing packs, the challenges are the same as Arkham Asylum, only the maps and the new moves change. For me, it's not really enjoyable, some challenges are too hard and require 1 hour of play doing nothing to get all the medals. Boring.
The DLC Quinn's Revenge is quite good, a bit too short.
If you're an achievement master, you will probably end the story campaign 99.50% with 3 Riddler's challenges that you can do only once in the middle of the story.

To brief, this game has an awesome story that will get you curious of every single event in Arkham, The Joker is brilliant, I wonder what he's become in Arkham Origins. And if you didn't play Arkham Asylum, buy the triple pack.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City is a fantastic successor to Batman: Arkham Asylum and it surpasses the Asylum in almost every way, with a deep open world and atmosphere, interesting characters, and an outstanding story.
The gameplay we've come to know and love from the Arkham series has been refined and refurbished, boss fights are more varied and combat was much improved, there are so many ways to knock people down, using hand to hand combat, gadgets or just take them down in stealth...

The story and side missions will take a while to finish. Batman: Arkham City is an amazing game that ranks as one of the top games this generation.

Batman: Arkham City is a must have game!!!

10/10

reviewText: 3 out of 5, fun at first, disjointed, repetitive and boring later.  I LOVED LOVED LOVED Asylum, but this game does not live up to the fun of the first.  This game takes place in a much larger world than the first game, however the world is boring and lifeless, and you will spend most of your time doing busywork to upgrade your character.  With all of the side missions this is a lengthy game, I wish they focused more on the core story.  The fun Riddler riddles from the first game have been replaced tons of boring easy puzzles.  It's not a bad game, but nowhere near as good as 1.  The boss battles are good.  In the first game you likely left detective mode turned on the whole game, in this game they made detective mode worse, encouraging you to turn it off.

reviewText: The second installment of the frenchise, and though I'm not a fan of the comic-book, nor the cartoons or movies, the game is extremely fun to play and the story keeps you glued to the monitor. The graphics are great, and the feeling, especially when executing the combat moves, is awesome. It has a HUGE array of side-missions to keep you going, an extremely large arsenal of gadgets and, oh, did I also mention you can play as cat-woman as well? And when that happens, it's like another game alltogether, it changes the gameplay a whole lot, you can crawl onto walls and take down unsuspecting enemies (just to give you a little spoiler), not to mention that the combat moves are sooo sexy. ;) Not only that, but especially if you're a fan of the series, having missions where you play as Robin as well is also exciting, seeing the main story develop through another perspective. Awesome game, full-hartedly recommend it!

reviewText:
Arkham City is a solid step up from Arkham Asylum. The world isn't necessarily bigger, but it's more densely packed with trophies, side missions, and baddies. The Riddler challenges are improved, but honestly I still needed some help to understand what the goal was of some of the trophies.

The story and characters are still good, the voiceover work is great, but I was still left wondering why I should care about any of the events. I love Batman, but even he asks near the end: What's the point of locking you up when you're just going to get out and wreak havoc again?"

It feels like by restricting everything Batman does to a prison area

reviewText:
Best. Game. Ever.

I will go over 5 topics in this review.
Story, Gameplay, Graphics, Sound and Replay Value

First off The Story.
It is around 12-15 hours all-up storywise and it is truely gripping and a great premise. Without spoiling anything, The game is set a couple of years after Arkham Asylum, and the newly appointed mayor Quincy Sharp Ex Warden of old Arkham Asylum has created a super prison dubbed ARKHAM CITY, Sure just throw all the bad guys in one place and throw away the key, Like thats gonna work!

It's up to Batman to sort all this out, by punching every Super-Villan in the face!

The Character list in the main game, not to mention the side missions is huge, more than I can say but from the trailers of course you have Hugo Strange, The Joker, Two-Face, Catwoman, The Riddler, EVEN Solomon Grundy is here, if you like the comics you will love the detail the devs have put into this game.

Next Gameplay, what good is an amazing story without gameplay?
You for the most part of the game play as BATMAN, the worlds greatest Crimefighter and Detective, Both of which are put to work as you Grappel around the place, glide, Throw Batman's Signature Batarangs and fire his disarming Bat-Claw, and of course the magnificent FreeFlow combat from the previous game upscaled and infused with more awesome. Double Takedowns, Counters (Or more if those thugs dare hitting you at the same time!) The combat is improved dramatically and encouraging more use of using your gadgets more than ever during your combat and it really pays to do so!

Graphics:
I am not one to judge a game by its Graphics usually... But this game, is really pretty! So much detail in the enviroments you fly around in and well rendered character models all make this game truely immersive!

Sound:
The games sound is standout both in its strong epic soundtrack and the Excellent voice acting brought to us again in both Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamil repectively as Batman and The Joker, and the countless other characters from supporting characters like Alfred and Oracle to the complaining of the thugs you encounter on the street as Batman, this level of Voice Acting really makes the experience come alive.

Replay Value:
In addition to the main story you have a bunch of side quests, which are varied and interesting to play through and give Batman more time to show off his Detective Skills.

The Riddler is the largest side mission, he has hidden large amounts of riddler trophies and created riddles all over Arkham City for Batman to collect and solve, and you won't turn a blind eye to this if you did in the previous game, the Riddler has hostages who he will kill if Batman doesn't solve enough of his riddles before the night is over. Also completing the Riddlers Challenges unlock Concept art and 3-D Character trophies for you to look at in the main menu which is sweet if you are into that!

Aside from the many side quests there is a seperate gamemode called New Game Plus unlocked after you complete the game on Normal/Hard, which allows you to play the story again, With all of your upgrades!
The Catch? No Counter icons in combat, and pretty much everything about the gameplay has gotten four times as hard. (Good Luck Beating Two-Face as Catwoman :P)

Once you have done all of this to keep you entertained there is a mode called Riddlers Revenge" a bunch of small levels usually of either Plain Combat or Predator rooms each of which you have to complete objectives for to get a High Score on that Leaderboard!"

Batman Arkham City - The Sequel to the critically Acclaimed Batman Arkham Asylum.

reviewText:
I quite liked the first game, despite not being a fan of Batman so I had high hopes for this second instalment.

Arkham Asylum was set in the titular Arkham Asylum / prison, making it a confined experience where you slowly gained access to new buildings and learned your way around the place.

Arkham City, in contrast, is set in a cordoned off segment of Arkham City (yup, still some super literal titling going on) where all villains are running rampant. This allows the player to run around in an open-world sandbox, fulfil side missions, gather collectibles, play as catwoman and generally just have fun.
It sounded almost too good to be true...

Unfortunately, it kind of was.
Arkham City, compared to its predecessor, feels unfocussed and poorly optimized. The large areas (including the seamless outdoor area that is the city) look great, but can have some framerate drops, especially when travelling at high speeds (e.g. with the grappling hook).
Combat, which was relatively slow but delightfully impactful-feeling in the original has been sped up a bit for Batman and a lot for newcomer Catwoman. It suits Catwoman's style, but in Batman's case it feels as if his punches are less effective.

Don't get me wrong though, this is still an excellent game that I would recommend, even to non-fans like myself.
The story is solid (while also silly, it's a super hero game after all! Don't expect this game to just be gritty situations like the recent DC films)

If you haven't played the first game yet, start there.
If you have, know that this might not be quite as good, but still a fun game.
Oh, and ignore Origins, that game is a mess.

reviewText:
Back in 2011, I first played Arkham City on PS3, and I thought it was a near-perfect video game. A meticulously-detailed world, where every building, wall, and street thug tells a story, incredible characters oosing with wit and personality, and an expansion over the gameplay mechanics that made the original Arkham Asylum a classic is just the tip of the iceberg of what makes this game special. I, at the time, was convinced that Rocksteady could not have made a better game, and rewarded it a perfect score. There were no stupid bugs, glitches, or any breaks in the pacing. It was a long, meaty game that kept being at the top of its class from beginning to end.

Fast forward to 2016, and here I'm revisiting it again via the GOTY Edition on PC. I thought I was overhyping the game my first go-around, since it was brand new at the time, and decided to see if it still held up as highly as I once thought of it. Thankfully, good gameplay doesn't get old, and while the graphics have since been surpassed by the excellent Arkham Knight, the artistry still stands tall here. The GOTY Edition includes a variety of goodies, like costumes, new missions, and most important of them all: Catwoman.

Catwoman wasn't in my original playthrough of the game, but her inclusion in this package extends the length of the overall adventure by at least a few hours. Her adventures happen during the events of the game, and the story switches perspectives between Batman and Catwoman at certain points. The Catwoman stuff isn't essential to the main story, but it is a welcome change of pace, since she controls differently and features her own set of moves. That would be the biggest reason to get the GOTY edition over the standard one, on top of a post-story mission that is also included.

tl;dr Arkham City is the best Batman game I will probably ever play, and one of the best games of the seventh generation. Even half a decade later, the writing's on the wall. This is Rocksteady's magnum opus.

reviewText:
Mix up Batman : Arkham Asylum with more cinematics, more polished combat, a bigger map with a LOT more secrets and what do you get?
An epic game: Batman: Arkham City

Here are my Pros and Cons, why you should, or not, get this game.

Pros:
+ Huge Arkham City with a LOT of secrets
+ Same Great combat system, like in Asylum
+ Great voice acting
+ Arkham Asylum was a must-play, Arkham City continues the tradition
+ Sexy Catwoman
+ Engaging story that will pull you back for..one more checkpoint...
+ PC version is superior to the console one

Cons:
- Some villains could be more emphasized
- Some side quests might feel repetitive after a while

Some say City is a better game than it's predecessor, but I personally prefer the Asylum, nevertheless this does not make out of City a lesser game.
A must buy for any Batman fan and not only, for any action fan it's a joy to play this game.

It's a 9/10 game for me.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=toFY3Ns6_zA

reviewText: I'll start of by saying this game had the best superhero campaign I have ever played. This is the only game in which I did not skip any cutscenes and enjoyed all of them; the script was written so excellent that you feel like they are truly talking to you. Like how Joker tries to talk to you and makes you oblivious to the tricks he has up his sleeves, or someone like Two-Face who just yells at his henchmen to blow you to bits! The gameplay is flawless and smooth without any hiccups, and it's also easy to learn for anyone new to the game. I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who likes to play video games, because not only is this a game for comic book fans but it's an game for every gamer out there. 10/10.

reviewText: One of the best games I've ever played. The game has all you want: a good main story, interesting side-quests, many of the Batman important enemies from the comics are in this game, boss battles (especially Mr. Freeze and Ra's al Ghul battles) are very well done, voice actors fit the characters very good (especially Mark Hamill voice as Joker), an awesome soundtrack, good PC optimization (this game runs on a weak laptop with high settings), and also the fighting system is perfectly done, encouraging you to use gadgets or stealth. As cons, I would have liked the city to be bigger and the game to have some events like Crime alerts from Arkham Origins.\n\nIn conclusion, this game is 9.5/10, and definitely one of the best games ever made. It doesn't matter if you aren't a Batman fan, this game would make you one. Also I recommend before playing this game to play Arkham Asylum.

reviewText:
First of all I want to say that Batman Arkham City is the best open world game ever made(honestly it falls on top 3 as others may like different games)

I have only 60+ hours on Steam version of this game, before I bought a gaming PC I used to play this game on a cloud gaming service called Onlive, and there I have 250+ hours on this game. Played this game so much because I really like this game.

Riddler Trophies are an interesting part of this game. Some of them require some thinking, I collected all 440 trophies.

The best part about this game I like is the combat and beating up thugs. The challenge maps are so fun. The most 2 fun challenge maps are Iceberg Lounge and Joker's Funhouse.
Iceberg Lounge has unlimited wave of enemies that you could fight as long as you survive. I once got a 1157 combo in that map.And Joker's Funhouse is also another fun map that makes you keep on playing on you start learning not to get hit and how to keep on going.

I totally recommend this game, it has great graphics, very well optimized. Totally worth every dollar and penny you spend on it.

reviewText:
This is an extended review on Batman: Arkham City.

Content: 9/10
With a 15+ hours of campaign story, challenges - DLC ones included, character trophies, concept art, character bios and stories in-game which you can read or listen to and Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC (which is a 1-2 hours story for what happened after the events of the game) you have in your hands a 30+ hours (or more) of gameplay that can easily be expanded upon with the New Game Plus" option. Plenty of value here.

Graphics: 9/10
There is a small improvement over Arkham Asylum's visuals here
date:
not that it matters though! This game is visually excellent and its strong even when you dont compare it to the prequel game. Great detail at max settings for a console port.

Aesthetics: 10/10
The gritty environment of an abandoned city-prison is perfectly caught here. There is high detail at every turn so as Batman you feel at home!

Sound: 9/10
- Sound Quality: Excellent. Just that.

reviewText:
Awesome game. Truly one of the greatest.

The controls are sharp even though you still cannot adjust the mouse sensitivity as I hoped but the camera speed is fast enough. There is still some sloppiness and slight delay when it comes to moving around. For instance just like in the first game, there are preset points where your grappling hook works - you can't pick your spots. Initially, there are too many HUD oriented hints, and even though you can turn off some, you cannot turn them all off. The game itself doesn't have that much hud especially in-doors which is a good thing in my opinion because it helps the immersion.

The city map is small. REALLY small by today's standards at least. It's at best 30 square blocks. But the good thing is that eventually you get access to restricted areas such as houses, mansions, sewers, etc. So you will be doing a lot of backtracking just like in the first game, only this time, you have an open map and not a series of large closed off areas to navigate in. Plus there is always something happening in the city and you will see the city change as you play. Barely anything is static.

The gameplay (battle-wise). I feel like it changed slightly for worst in some areas. The first game would literally force you to watch your enemies and anticipate their movies so you could counter-attack. This time it's different. This time you will see several lightening bolts flash above enemies that are about to attack you. This warning throws me off because it decreases the challenge and realism. However, if you want to play the second time on hardest mode then these warnings disappear which is neat. On the other hand, the fighting is at the same time easier than in the first game because you can actually counter-several enemies who are about to punch you at the same time - something you couldn't do in the first game.

More so, what's tedious is that this time you will be battling sometimes about a dozen of enemies at a time. You will rarely be able to finish off your enemies while they are on the ground because you will be overwhelmed for the most part. While playing the PS3 version, my thumb frequently got tired at the time of battling. But that problem when away because of simply mouse clicks which do not require as much energy as tapping a button, evidently. So I actually did not die as many times as I did while playing the PS3 version.

Also, this time if you want to counter-attack CONSTANTLY and never get hit (Except for when they try to throw a trash can at you) is to simply tap right the right mouse button (NO TIMING REQUIRED this time). In the first game if you pressed the counter-attack button a lot earlier before the preceding attack, then you would get hit, even IF you pressed the same button right after. The first game really forced you to monitor your enemies closely and work out the algorithm of the fight you were in. But at least now you can counter-attack two enemies attacking you at the same time.

But eventually you get introduced to bigger and badder high-tech enemies that force you to employ different tactics (reminiscent of the last splinter cell game).

Another minus is that there is no blood in the game, again. (but yes I know that this is Batman Universe, the villains never die, they simply escape over and over and over again....)

Also, those annoying unrealistic bats that fly around you are still there. There's still no way to turn them off.

Also, this time around, there are even more unlockables to unlock. There are still Joker teeth, but now there are Penguin's penguin dolls, air balloons and other miscellaneous interactive items that need to be destroyed upon sight.

The story is engaging and ties itself well with the first game somewhat. Some villains as well as their demise gets mentioned so it's kind of cool to wonder what happened. The boss fights are okaish but the one that I didn't like was with that immortal dude. I mean the whole stage with him and the subsequent fight was just an excuse for Batman to fight some more (even though he was dreaming). Same applies tot he Mad Hatter stage of the game, it's just more fighting, albeit it is disturbing fighting. I think they could use more creativity with these stages. One of the best boss fights without a doubt is with Mr. Freeze, it can last for up to 20 minutes and you do have to use your brains. Sadly, that was the most developed boss battle in the entire game.

Also, barely ANY dialogue gets repeated, ever, except for sometimes. I'm surprised how much effort went into dialogue here, it's like watching a movie, a good Batman movie that is, ahem ahem.

The loading screen sometimes takes 11 seconds.

I also appreciate the remix of the Hans Zimmer soundtracks from the last two Batman movies. Nice touch. There's some inception there too.

The bosses and the characters are all so versatile and flamboyant. You get fully immersed in their personalities and you don't really want the villains dead you may want them hurt but you don't want them GONE because then you know that the fun is over. So the game makes you care even about the villains because aside from Batman that's what the Batman Universe if famous for. However, you do not really get to see too much of the villains. You only see the Two-Face a couple of times and you do not even see Killer Croc.

The amount of the Riddler riddles and tricks is insane. I'm not sure if that many were needed. I mean, they are supposed to be concealed better; they are supposed to take time to find and unlock like in the first game. Here you get a large portion of them practically for free, but as you progress you realize that Batman has a whopping 400 riddler secrets to unlock and the cat woman has 100. A small portion of them (like 5-10%) is extremely hard to solve, some require blind luck which is annoying.

The game is extremely well refined. Ever step and area is thought out, every engagement can still be approached differently so the gameplay will never get you bored. The artistic value of this game cannot be understated. The gangs and the bandits all have different allegiances to different villains, so it is a nice touch to see that not all villains team up with each other, they all have different missions and ideologies.

The amount of upgrades here is about 3-4 times than the amount in the first game and you retain most if not all of your abilities from the first game.

One of the downsides of this game being an open-worlded game is that quite often you will lose your sense of direction. You might weight out your priorities as to where it is you want to go. There's main mission and there are side missions and there are Riddler missions and there are miscellaneous missions. You might go into one direction only to realize that it's best if you went another direction. The first game didn't have that problem if you can call it that. Still, the world is not too big for you to get lost and it is not too small to be called a sand-box.

One of the downsides of the PS3 version was slow texture loading. I haven't experienced anything like that on PC. AND, the loading time between deaths is about twice as short as on the PS3, go figure.

Lastly, it's the same unreal engine from the last game; the water looks slightly better rendered on the PC, but it is not that great looking either.

reviewText:
I didn't enjoy Arkham City as much as Arkham Asylum, but it's still a great game and good continuation of the story. Everything else feels pretty much the same, which is a good thing... plus some new gadgets.

What Arkham Asylum did better: the whole reality breaking psychological tricks were much better in Arkham Asylum

What Arkham City did better: gave the opportunity to perch high and look down on the city, also gave additional playable characters that fit into the story with different gameplay styles

Scarecrow (who didn't make a return in Arkham City) is one of my favourite villains, and I love the reality breaking stuff so it stands to reason that I'd like the first game better, however both games absolutely deliver on what their titles promise: Batman in an asylum and Batman in a city.

reviewText:
How have I not reviewed this yet?

Arkham City is the sequel to Arkham Asylum, which was an excellent game itself.  I said a lot of great things about that game, and Arkham City improves on pretty much everything.

First, the combat.  The combat in Arkham Asylum was okay, but had some awkwardness.  This game is a little more forgiving and far more fluid when fighting, you'll notice the difference immediately if you've played the original game.  This along with a whole lot of new moves and better combos means fighting is more fun and interesting, and feels less stiff.

While Arkham Asylum took place on an island divided into three areas that loaded separately and were connected by passages, Arkham City takes a different approach to make it feel more like an open world.  The entire exterior map acts as one large area, and you can move freely across it, even though overall it is larger than the entire map of Arkham Asylum.  Interior areas still load separately, but the outside has eliminated loading screens and connector areas entirely.  It makes moving through Arkham City seamless.

Even better, with the improved controls, it is now possible to travel through the entire game world using glide without ever touching the ground.  It's amazing thing to see.  The glide system was overhauled, allowing new actions during gliding, such as diving, giving Batman near-flight powers.  The grapnel gun was also upgraded, with a boost mechanism that instead of pulling you to a location allows you to gain momentum and shoot out into the sky.  The grapnel gun can easily be used in mid-glide, now.  This makes travelling around the city both exciting and easy, instead of tedious.

Another nice touch is the addition of another character.  In the storyline (Game of the Year Edition), the plot alternates between Batman and Catwoman, both are playable.  Catwoman's moves are completely different from Batman's, which makes a nice change.  Unfortunately, for most of the game the switching is mandatory, meaning you have to finish a Catwoman segment to continue as Batman, and the transitions between the characters are cliffhangers.  Eventually, you will get the option to switch back and forth between them.

The story is excellent, and plays into the foreshadowing in Arkham Asylum.  The Warden, Quincy Sharpe, is now the mayor of Gotham, and following Joker's takeover of Arkham, ordered both the Asylum and Blackgate shut down, and a rundown section of Gotham was designated a maximum security prison, the new Arkham City.  This setting means most of Batman's regular foes can all be running loose in one crime-infested area, with no one to stop them, which gives villains like Penguin and Two-Face a lot of time to shine after being left out of the previous game.  Joker and Harley Quinn remain the biggest threat to Batman, but something strange is going on with Joker.  Few people have actually seen him, and rumor is that he is very ill after the Arkham Asylum incident.  But Joker is not the only mastermind in Arkham City, not in the least.

The ending is stunning.  I was shocked.  I won't spoil it.  All I will say is I won't hear the song Only You" the same ever again.

I know I used a lot of words
date: but I didn't come close to talking about everything good about this game.  It really is great.  Definitely recommended."

reviewText:
Fantastic game, very polished, great gameplay.

The graphics are slightly cartoonish/stylized as they should be for a batman game. The game essentially takes place at night, and the lighting looks great. It felt very immersive and I rarely felt like something was just a texture or polygon (a problem i have with most games i.e. Bioshock Infinite)

Gameplay is part fantastic brawler, and part stealth action. Traversing the open world is grappling and gliding (with some climbing if you feel like it); this system worked way better than i expected.
Brawling is smooth and can be difficult.
You have many gadgets at your disposal, and the stealth really makes you feel like the Bat. Swooping down at taking out a baddie, then 5 seconds later drop another enemy on the other side of the room really makes you feel powerful.

Even if you are powerful, Batman is far from invincible; guns do a lot of damage, so you have to plan each move. While you have a lot of gadgets, its all non-lethal, and the non-lethal aspect can make the game more difficult than other stealth games where you can just shoot baddies in the head from cover. The game makes you become Batman. It captures the essence of Batman more than i could have hoped.

Catwoman and others have their distance combat and movement styles, this keeps the game very interesting.

The only gripes i have: In one scene Batman is coughing, the same audio clip is played over and over. This like a minute of the game, a really minor detail. The other gripe is the line-launcher. Its a late-story gadget, and it can be very janky. After all the other gadgets doing what you want them to, the line-laucher can be finicky and i had to keep retrying a couple platforming parts.

Voice acting is great, story is great, open world is great, gameplay is great, graphics are great, music is great.
Why are you still reading this, just play this game (when it goes on sale for 5$ you have no reason to not buy it)

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City GOTY is a open world 3rd person beat 'em up, the sequel to Batman: Arkham Asylum. I had a lot of fun playing it, and it was an unique experience.

The whole Arkham City is used as a prison. The city is big, and looks amazing, each area is unique and beautiful, from Selina Kyle's apartment with her cats out of the window, to a frozen police and a clown infested steel meel. You will glide from place to place, leap, climb, dive kick enemies, and use your grapling hook to climb from rooftop to rooftop. The most of enemies are in the streets, there are new villains and almost all of them have their own gang. The enemies are different, from brawlers, gun wielders, armored brawlers to snipers, knife wielders, shielded brawlers and stun batoners. Batman just has one attack button to use and Batman will do all of the punching, kicks, sweeps and brawling himself. There is seriously an incredible amount of attacks, finishing moves, counters, etc. you will enjoy fighting even the weakest foe. You can also counter incoming enemy attacks, some enemies need to be stunned, or a special move to be killed. The gun users are the harderst, because you will die quickly if they start shooting at you, here is where the stealth comes in. You have to climb to high places, hide in grates, or just corner cover and silently assassinate every one of the thugs. The AI of the gunners is great, they'll patrol, warn others when they find a downed ally. In combat, you can also use batarangs, shock blasts, freeze grenades and other useful gadgets, but not only in combat, these gadgets are used to help you progress further and solve puzzles.  Multiple batterangs, remote control batterangs, to help you hit things you can't normally reach, a zip-line, explosive gel, a grappling hook to rip down high up grates, a new smoke bomb to hide when you've been spotted, freeze grenades, which are good for floating through the sewers, an electricity gun for powering devices like garage doors, a hacking device to break into security and also detective mode that lets you see hints, such as highlighting enemies, seeing them through objects, lit up gargoyles you can grapple onto, doors, grates, footprints, sniper rifle trajectories and the Riddler's riddle. During your adventure you will also play as Catwoman, which I find very interesting and fun, she has a very fast paced combat, she uses her whip to get around, also climb walls and ceiling, and she has new unique gadgets. Everything is fully voiced, every NPC, villain, thug, Batman and Catwoman. You'll hear thugs discussing things, along with radio transmissions every so often. The main quests took around 14h for me to complete, which I think its an ok amount of time, but keep in mind there are side quests too which are very good and take much more to complete, they feel like extra storylines and also many Riddler trophies and challanges to complete, also very well detailed. There is also the Riddler Challange mode, which are challenge rooms like the first game had. Combat rooms where you get a high score beating up waves enemies, ''predator maps'' that require you to take out gunmen in specific ways to beat the challenges and even downloadable challenge rooms, mini campaigns and even a make your own challenge map where you chose a map and select goals. You'll also get to select your character from Batman, Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing with costumes to choose from. This also comes with Harley Quinn's revenge DLC, for 1-2 extra hours where you play as Batman and Robin, a quick good story.

The graphics look really good, and with many awesome details, the story is also really interesting. The soundrack is great, and so is the voice acting. There are many voice acting stars such as: the Joker who is voiced by Luke Skywalker  Kevin Conroy as Batman, and Tara Strong, Nolan North and Maurice LaMarce.

I strongly recommend this game, great combat system, great story, soundtrack, voice acting and graphics 10/10.

reviewText: Batman : Arkham City is a very good open-world action title with a heavy emphasis on exploration. With interesting boss fights (a nice upgrade from the first game), a very slick and balanced gameplay that manages to balance stealthy segments with more action-packed ones, and great visual identity, Arkham City establishes itself as a solid AAA title that follows in the footsteps of its predecessor for great results.  The game is filled to the brim with content ; while the main story can be beaten in about 15 hours, the many sidequests and collectibles will grab dedicated players' attention. Also worth noting are the numerous iconic characters from the Batman lore that make an appearance, whether during the main storyline or during sidequests. This will most certainly satisfy hardcore fans of the franchise, while being a great way to introduce newcomers, as each appearing character is given a biography that the player can read at any time.\n\nThe elements that disappointed me were the simplistic combat system (not really improved since the previous title), the upgrades that sometimes felt like they were only useful for one specific situation ; and the story, while more developed than in the previous title, did not quite make up for the slightly underwhelming and subdued overall atmosphere that clashed with the oppressive, almost intoxicating setting of Arkham Asylum. All in all, Batman Arkham City is really enjoyable, and although it is not revolutionary by any means, I recommend it wholeheartedly to anyone with as much as a passing interest in the Batman universe.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved Batman: Arkham Asylum. It was a spectacular look into the asylum itself, a location that stole the show, transformed and twisted by the inmates over the course of the game and providing ample room to explore. The plot wasn't groundbreaking, but it was great, and the spectacular returns of Animated Series cast members were accompanied by other great performances across the board. Most importantly, it gave the player an experience no other game could attest to: The feeling of becoming The Bat, learning his methods and feeling the tension he never expresses. When I heard about Arkham City, I doubted that a sequel could do it justice.

Those doubts have been blasted out of the frikkin' water.

The mere concept of Arkham City as a location cleverly serves several purposes: The reasons you'll uncover over the course of the game, a chance to explore much of Gotham City while staying in criminal territory, a way to bring together enemies both criminally insane and just downright criminal, and a warning that this is all-new, untrodden territory. Sure, there are a ton of thematic illusions to classic Batman works, as in Asylum, but while Asylum stuck to a composite of other works, City creates a new blend of characters all its own, and does quite well in doing so. A lot of characters we write off nowadays as pathetic jokes are brought back up to the terrifying, vicious foes they're meant to be.

The vocal talents on display here are fantastic once again, although I personally got a little annoyed at Nolan North voicing every other goon. (To be fair, he does an excellent job as Penguin. I just feel the lack of vocal variety for enemies stands out.) I was disappointed to hear that Arleen wasn't voicing Harley this time around, but Tara Strong takes the role and runs with it like it was hers from the start. Everyone on the cast slips into these roles quite naturally.

Anyways! Combat is quite well evolved from Arkham Asylum, and just as thrilling as before. The quickfire" options took me quite a while to actually figure out

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City is a spectacle fighting/partial stealth game featuring (you guessed it) the Batman.

Plot:
Batman is captured by Hugo Strange and sent into Arkham City, the super prison built in part of Gotham. Batman soon learns of Protocol 10"
date:
which Strange says will make him famous. Batman begins his quest to stop Hugo Strange and his Protocol 10 to save Gotham city. Notable villains include:
-Hugo Strange
-Two-Face
-Penguin
-Mr. Freeze
-Ra's al-Ghul
-Joker
All of the characters are very well done with phenomenal voice acting. Most notably are Batman voiced by Kevin Conroy and Joker voiced by Mark Hamill (HEEEEEEHEHEEhehehee AHAAAAAAAAAHHHHAAAAhooo HA HEHEEE heee heee)

Gameplay:
You will spend the majority of the game as the Dark Knight himself
recommended: and there's a reason he is "The most dangerous man in the world"
hoursPlayed: as Superman once said. The gameplay can be split into four basic categories:\n\nBatman is a master of all forms of martial arts
voteText: and it shows. The combat is focused on a free-flow brawl which utilizes combos after 8 uninterrupted moves and is very responsive and satisfying. The right click to counter system works very well and is very enjoyable to play.\n\nHe is the Dark Knight for a reason after all. Not all thugs are simply using their fists to try and beat you to death
helpfulPercent: some have found that bullets are far more effective. Now begins the stealth portions of the game
votesHelpful: which are just as fun as the brawling. Stealth focuses around Takedowns. Takedowns can be silent
votesTotal: loud
votesFunny: terrifying
commentsCount: and much more. The thugs in the room have a very realistic reaction to things. I love (perhaps a bit too much) terrorizing thugs as I zip around
column16: breaking more than a few of their bones.\n\nArkham City is a big place
column17: and the sidewalk just ain't gonna cut it. Batman uses the Batclaw (his grapple gun) to zip around Arkham City in a very enjoyable manner. He can also use his cape to glide around like the bat he is. Parkour in the game is also very well done: not very complicated
column18: but very effective.\n\nAnd of course
column19: what would Batman be without his toolbelt? At your disposal are all sorts of gadgets available to the Bat at any time. These gadgets range from the Batclaw
column21: explosive gel
column22: and the classic Batarang. His gadgets are all unique in their own way
column23:
each with their own puprose and all very useful.

Graphics:
The game has great graphics and the in game cutscenes transition very well to actual gameplay. I don't have much else to say
column25:
I highly recommend this game. When I got it I didn't expect to play it that much. I don't like fighting games all too much. After 5 hours (straight) of "I'M BATMAN" I changed my mind.


Also:
I'M BATMAN"

reviewText:
Arkham city, Arkham city...

This is a remarkable video game in its time, just like Starcraft I in 1998, the 1st Tomb Raider game in 1996, Counter-Strike(in 2000) which presenting an absolutely shocking gameplay visual experience to  the gamers who shares the same love and passion for Action & Adventure Titles.

There's no such a way to say you're an AA titlle fan with Arkham City missing in your library.

Combined and bonded with a new introduced friendly combat system that is pretty easy to get on with, a never-seen before predator mode and comic-like riddle challenging storyline, an AA game just can never be that attractive, it made me dig into it with hours and hours and eventually even drowned into it, I can hardly pull myself back.

It is significant to say, if you're a lover of original Batman comic book, by playing the game within, you should by now notice what amazing work Rocksteady had done with the vital part of the game, and how well they mastered the universe of the hero of Batman along with his epic opponents.

The driven-stroy made AC stands out of the crowd, and somehow, it made me feel this is also a true Batman movie suppose to be.

I personally believe a timeless game is: After 200 hours+ gameplay
date: I would not be tired of it
recommended: and instantly come back to enjoy it once more. After years and years pass by
hoursPlayed: there's nothing else could replace it in the throne of my heart. Arkham City is
voteText: the very few games that makes me feel this way.\n\nIt is 2 years now since it's first released

they will last forever.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City is a highly recommended game if you’re into an open world action-adventure game. You get the chance to play Batman and Catwoman in Arkham City; a prison fortress controlled by Hugo Strange. Besides Hugo Strange, you’ll run into other Batman’s foes however I won’t give list the names since it will spoil the story.

Playing Batman is fantastic. You got access to Batman’s gadgets that will help him in any errand he’s in and let’s not forget his cape. The game takes place in an abandoned city so you’ll get the chance to glide with minimum sound and attack the thugs by stealth. There are a lot of stealth methods to be applied so it’s about planning attacks. Sometimes I improvised to make it more authentic and that was such a cool experience! This game is the sequel to Batman - Arkham Asylum so I suggest trying that game as well.

Peace.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved Batman: Arkham Asylum. It was a spectacular look into the asylum itself, a location that stole the show, transformed and twisted by the inmates over the course of the game and providing ample room to explore. The plot wasn't groundbreaking, but it was great, and the spectacular returns of Animated Series cast members were accompanied by other great performances across the board. Most importantly, it gave the player an experience no other game could attest to: The feeling of becoming The Bat, learning his methods and feeling the tension he never expresses. When I heard about Arkham City, I doubted that a sequel could do it justice.

Those doubts have been blasted out of the frikkin' water.

The mere concept of Arkham City as a location cleverly serves several purposes: The reasons you'll uncover over the course of the game, a chance to explore much of Gotham City while staying in criminal territory, a way to bring together enemies both criminally insane and just downright criminal, and a warning that this is all-new, untrodden territory. Sure, there are a ton of thematic illusions to classic Batman works, as in Asylum, but while Asylum stuck to a composite of other works, City creates a new blend of characters all its own, and does quite well in doing so. A lot of characters we write off nowadays as pathetic jokes are brought back up to the terrifying, vicious foes they're meant to be.

The vocal talents on display here are fantastic once again, although I personally got a little annoyed at Nolan North voicing every other goon. (To be fair, he does an excellent job as Penguin. I just feel the lack of vocal variety for enemies stands out.) I was disappointed to hear that Arleen wasn't voicing Harley this time around, but Tara Strong takes the role and runs with it like it was hers from the start. Everyone on the cast slips into these roles quite naturally.

Anyways! Combat is quite well evolved from Arkham Asylum, and just as thrilling as before. The quickfire" options took me quite a while to actually figure out
recommended: and I only understood how to do the knife counters until after completing the story (and all side missions (besides the AR stuff but we'll get to that later)). Stealth segments didn't feel quite as interesting to me as before
hoursPlayed: but that might just be nostalgia goggles and a bit of repetitive choices on my part.\n\nThe side missions are quite engaging and presented in a reasonably organic manner. I would go as far as to say that the only missions that legitimately suck and are never fun are the AR Training challenges. Finish the first four early on

reviewText:
Batman ir atgriezies soreiz tikai arkham city.

Jokers ir atgriezies, bet vel ar kopa ar citiem laundariem. Ja spele jau ir 3 dazadas bandas. Tev bus janoskaidro kas ir kas (neteiksu vairak) + vel speles gaita bus citas problemas.Spele sak paradities ari kaksieviete kas speli tikai paplasina.Spele ari blakus misjas kuras ilgu laiku neprasa bet tikai speli pagarina( bet dazreiz sanaca izmantot gidu). Protams paradas ari mans iecinitais riddlers ar vel sarezgitakam miklam.Kartes vairak nebus :D bet no ipasiem cilvekiem varesi uzzinat informaciju bet attelus bus pasam jamin.Sakas ari hostage glabsana. spele ir vairak upgrade un spelmantinas kas pa tiesam noder.Spele  ir mazak visadu bugu. Bet mans vienigais lielais - bija tad kad tu cinijies kaut kur uz jumta tu cilveku nevareji nomest(bet tas tak betmens vins cilvekus nenogalina).Kad izej speli paradas ari gameplay + kas ir tas SP bet vienigi sarezgitaks bez palidzibas ( ja tev kads sitis pasam bus tas jasaprot).Bus ari papildinajums ar robinu kas ir patiesam neilgs (to vini noslinkojusi). Pec speles iziesanas paradas ari kostimu izvele. Spele ir ari riddlera revange kura ir jadara vissadas lietas lai iegutu medelas (seit ir gan ko darit).Kopuma spele ir kluvusi vel aizraujosaka ir speletas 50h un vel ir jaturpina gameplay + un riddlera revenge.

9.9/10 patiesam man loti patika.


!*SPOILERS*!

Tad kad speli izgaju man baidija tas ka jokers ir beigts un nebus vairs tradicijas ka jokers ir galvenais laundaris , bet ceru ka arkham origins bus tik pat labs un interesants.

reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City is overwhelmingly great and atmospheric, everything in this game is great, more than great. The graphics, the sound effects and especially the music, the gameplay, and the storyline. Arkham City is one of the best games ever.  For me the thing that made Arkham City beautiful the most is its storyline and combat system.  The story has dozens of surprises, easter eggs for example, dozens of them that has connections with the main story, the sidequests and collectibles (riddler trophies unlockables like interview tapes) supports the main story giving the player background and an idea about key characters in the game. The game has a complete feeling when you finish it, the story isn't vague, not confusing, has few flaws, the storyline is nearly perfect. Plus the history of Arkham Asylum gives the game more background.

BTW, I played the game for more than 80 hours, Steam didn't record my playtime when I'm offline.
Still, Poison Ivy and Catwoman are so hot.
9.8 + .2 for Catwoman's sexy a$$.
10/10 would like to see Poison Ivy's vines all around Catwoman again

reviewText: Batman Arkham Asylum was a very well-received game, and its sequel introduces many improvements: an open world (though it is still very small), more playable characters (Batman, Catwoman, Robin, Nightwing), more gadgets, more combat moves, more riddles, more rumble maps, more enemy types, et cetera. An incredibly enjoyable game all-around.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
No wonder the reviews are overwhelmingly positive, I've found that both the brawler & predator gameplay mechanics (Fighting mobs & picking off armed baddies using hit & run tactics) are very rewarding, this, boosted by the implemented open-world setting and a lithe addition of rpg progression feature makes for an insanely fun time.
Not to mention I've personally found the optimalization of the game more than competent, it runs smoothly with graphic settings high enough to be entertaining on a PC that's rather humble by today's standards to say the least.

The addition of other playable characters and overall amount of content is just awesome, I recommend it to any fan of open-world fighting rps fans, not to mention I dare to say it's a must-have for Batman fans.

Um dos melhores jogos que já joguei 10/10

Sempre fui fã do Batman desde a minha infancia , assistindo animações , vendo filmes , lendo quadrinhos e etc . mas sempre ficava desepcionado com os jogos , maaas a rocksteady realizou o meu sonho , tanto com seu titulo anterior , quanto com esse , Jogabilidade ♥♥♥♥ , Historia MUITO boa , digna de ser comparada com o quadrinho A piada Mortal , cujo o final lembra muito o do quadrinho , vc se sente na pele do Batman , vc vê ele se FODENDO , Cidade destruida , Crimes em gotham . trilha sonora ♥♥♥♥ , orquestrada e lembra bem a trilha sonora dos filmes do nollan . reviewText:
Arkham city, Arkham city...

This is a remarkable video game in its time, just like Starcraft I in 1998, the 1st Tomb Raider game in 1996, Counter-Strike(in 2000) which presenting an absolutely shocking gameplay visual experience to  the gamers who shares the same love and passion for Action & Adventure Titles.

There's no such a way to say you're an AA titlle fan with Arkham City missing in your library.

Combined and bonded with a new introduced friendly combat system that is pretty easy to get on with, a never-seen before predator mode and comic-like riddle challenging storyline, an AA game just can never be that attractive, it made me dig into it with hours and hours and eventually even drowned into it, I can hardly pull myself back.

It is significant to say, if you're a lover of original Batman comic book, by playing the game within, you should by now notice what amazing work Rocksteady had done with the vital part of the game, and how well they mastered the universe of the hero of Batman along with his epic opponents.

The driven-stroy made AC stands out of the crowd, and somehow, it made me feel this is also a true Batman movie suppose to be.

I personally believe a timeless game is: After 200 hours+ gameplay

reviewText: I recommended the first Batman: Arkham Asylum and I will definitely recommend Batman: Arkahm City.  Great smooth flowing hand to hand combat, wonderful variety of Batman toys to play with, and outstanding visuals and atmosphere.  Joker as usual is well voiced as is the rest of the cast.  The story isn't its strongest point, though it will carry some interest throughout its short campaign.  Then there's the riddler collectibles, the challenges and more.  Lots of fun.  Don't miss out on a great video game rendition of Batman.

reviewText:
Allow me, to give you an extravagant look at, batman, arkham city.


Soooooo, 1st off, we have da big bad boy gangs, we got joker gang, bane gang, and two-faced gang. Oh! and penguin's gang

Joker's gang is made of clowns, who look like they're on drugs :P
Bane's gang is SUPER ripped with muscles, beat da crap outta ya.
two-faced gang u beat in the 1st mission, they're wimps, compared to batman, of course.
Penguin's gang is made out of russian mercs, who shoot, A LOT.

Now, we discussed enenmies, now to gameplay

You literally beat the crap out of everyone you see, see a gangster? BEAT HIM UP!!!! It's really funny, cuz, the last guy gets ZOOMED IN and SLOW MOTIONED when u finish him, so boss.

Ummmmmmmm, what else? OH YEAH, STORY.

I CANT STAHP PLAYING!!! the story is really intriguing, and the side missions are also fun every now and then.

Not to give any spoilers, so, i'll stop the story there.

Costumes!!!

They look cool

Hobos!!!
You can just do whatever, talk to them, beat them up, uhmmmmmmmm, yeah? thats it for the hobos.

TV REPORTERS!!!

Yeah, these guys actually chase you down, and try to interview you, i blew up one of their helicopter's once, soooooo, no mo' tv fo' you guys!!!!

Boss fights!!!

MMmmmmm, pretty cool, i like the finishing blows, also slow-motion.

PUZZLES
Cool.



These usually take 5 mins or so, but, it's ok, pretty easy.

FREE-ROAMING, AND MESSING AROUND

So boss, running around, stopping robberies and mugs, and, once i even stopped a civilian breaking into a home, soooooo, arkham is pretty cray-cray, people robbing and muggin' at every corner.


NANANANANANNANANA BATMAN!!!

So, im gonna wrap this up, by rating it, outta 10

9/10

WOULD STOP A CIVILIAN FROM BREAKING INTO A GUY'S HOME AGAIN!!!


And, remember kids, NANANANANANAN BATMAN!!! :D

So, uh, cya guys later!!! i'll be doin' batman stuff


EDIT: I finally finished batman arkham city, and, ITS DEFINTLEY the best, if not one of the best, games i've ever played, in my life!!!

GREAT GAME!!! ending is so dramatic, and awesome!!!!!!!!!!!! :D

reviewText:
While the first entry shows how a Batman video game should be made, the second one takes you to a new level. Well let me break down some details for you.

a.Story
The story of Batman has never been this frustrating. On the first series, Batman has been made confused by the infamous evil Joker's plan. Doctor Hugo Strange, Ra's al Ghul, and once again, Joker, put him on hard times even more than ever where he has to put down the chaos made in Arkham City in. Very interesting and engaging.

b.Gameplay
We know that Batman, among the Justice League, is the weakest. But, in the game he actually a badass. The free flow combat system makes him really strong and gives an awesome feeling when you hit the last enemy within a combo chain. You can also access many gadgets the dark knight can offer. Fantasy of being the bat came true.

c.Graphics
I really like look of the game. The aura of Arkham City nightmare is felt really well. Atmosphere of injustice brings down upon the chaotic city of Arkham. What I like the most is that it can run on my computer very well with almost no performance issues.

d.Replayability
It is always good to back as The Dark Knight". You can choose different customisation (character upgrade) from previous playthrough and try to play the hardest difficulty. Well
date: if you don't fancy yourself challenge modes
recommended:
have yourself a new game plus.

Verdict
It is the best Batman game
hoursPlayed:
beating bad guys on the streets in the most dangerous area out there in the world to bring justice is very noble.

Verdict
9.0"
voteText: December 10, 2014
helpfulPercent: true
votesTotal: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wow, a sequel that actually stepped up everything from the prior game, cool.

The combat is improved from the already solid combat from AA, with almost every gadget available as a quickfire weapon, instead of just batarangs and grappling hooks. The main story is cool, the Riddler expanded his operation (there are now 440 items/puzzles between Batman and Catwoman), and actually shows up in person. Pretty much every major Batman villain shows up and has stuff for you to do, either as part of the main story or as their own set of side quests.

The challenge mode expanded. There is a campaign mode that picks a few challenges for you to do consecutively, with small changes to make things easier or harder, (e.g. no silent takedowns, or batarangs that KO instantly), or you can pick your own group of challenges. There's also a mission that just throws thugs at you until you die, which is great fun.

Robin and Nightwing are really fun to use, but it's unfortunate that they can't fly around the city like Batman and Catwoman can. Robin is at least playable in the Harley DLC, but Nightwing is restricted to challenge mode.

RE: Harley DLC
It was cool, though you can't freeroam with Robin, and I thought Harley's voice was pretty shrill at times.

tl;dr
Everything was improved upon, 10/10, GOTY, etc.

reviewText:
My very first Batman Arkham game :3. From what i think, this is the best Batman Arkham game i've played. This game actually runs pretty well on some low-end pc:s out there (If you lower the graphics a bit).
+Clever storyline
+Realistic graphics
+Lots of side missions
+Large open map
+Great audio
+Most fluent combat in the series (Haven't tried arkham knight yet)
+And you can get the DLC's (harley quinn's revenge, challenges etc.) for FREE!
-Couple minor bugs, but they are funny!

One of those games that everyone should try, cause i loved it <3. I've completed the game once perfectly (100%), all the riddler trophies twice and the story four times. It was kewl that the developers have managed to make the game's riddle's revenge (the combat challenges and campaings) so interesting somehow! :D

reviewText:
A realistic shooting experience that takes you on a trip to Aurora, Colorado, where you will be introduced to the protagonist James Holmes.
After a quick introduction to being mentally ill, dying your hair in a way that makes you look like a surprised carrot, and finally getting your AR15, which as well all have been taught is essential to daily survival next to shelter, clothing, and food, you will encounter the enemies of the first level. Do not be fooled! These stone cold monsters are portrayed as harmless cinema enthusiasts.
Beware ... pure evil sleeps within their deceptive popcorn buckets and soft drink bottles.
The hope for salvation of the whole world lies in your hands, and your hands only. Your finger, the trigger, the blood rage - the essential holy trinity of this mission.
Young hero, be prepared to show no mercy to these traitors. You must succeed.


Oh, wait ..

reviewText:
This is an insta classic game. 10/10!

Arkham City is on of the best game's i played last 5 years.
I could tell you millions of reasons why to own this game but i will for fast forward...

a) The visuals are Freaking amazing, and the game is AMAZINGLY renderd without the need of a super computer to play it on max settings.
b)Music and game sounds are so intence you will catch yourself squeezing your mouse in fights or chaces with a stupid smile in your face.
c)Gameplay is perfect. You can roam around city gliding like a bat or you can kick 20 peaple's ♥♥♥ on the ground with 40x combos screaming out of pleasure. Everything works like a charm.
d)Storyline is great without needing a previus game explanation for what is going on. Most of gamers knows the enemys anyway from comics, cartoons or movies.
e)Replayability? Well, i finished the main storyline in about 9 hours. After that i did some missions which they where totally AWESOME feeling like i was still playing the main story. I 'll say 3-5 more hours there. Riddles could take you days to solve, adding more time. You can restart the game with all your upgrades in a harder mode and dont forget the GOTY edition with huge amount of extras and an extra story line with the amazing Harley Queen! :p I'd say 25-35 hours of pure gameplay and more of 50hours for the 100% achiv.

The best game i played this year so far! BUY IT ALREADY!

c.Graphics
I really like look of the game. The aura of Arkham City nightmare is felt really well. Atmosphere of injustice brings down upon the chaotic city of Arkham. What I like the most is that it can run on my computer very well with almost no performance issues.

d.Replayability
It is always good to back as The Dark Knight". You can choose different customisation (character upgrade) from previous playthrough and try to play the hardest difficulty. Well
date: if you don't fancy yourself challenge modes
recommended:
have yourself a new game plus.

Verdict
It is the best Batman game
hoursPlayed:
beating bad guys on the streets in the most dangerous area out there in the world to bring justice is very noble.

Verdict
9.0"

reviewText:
Wow, a sequel that actually stepped up everything from the prior game, cool.

The combat is improved from the already solid combat from AA, with almost every gadget available as a quickfire weapon, instead of just batarangs and grappling hooks. The main story is cool, the Riddler expanded his operation (there are now 440 items/puzzles between Batman and Catwoman), and actually shows up in person. Pretty much every major Batman villain shows up and has stuff for you to do, either as part of the main story or as their own set of side quests.

The challenge mode expanded. There is a campaign mode that picks a few challenges for you to do consecutively, with small changes to make things easier or harder, (e.g. no silent takedowns, or batarangs that KO instantly), or you can pick your own group of challenges. There's also a mission that just throws thugs at you until you die, which is great fun.

Robin and Nightwing are really fun to use, but it's unfortunate that they can't fly around the city like Batman and Catwoman can. Robin is at least playable in the Harley DLC, but Nightwing is restricted to challenge mode.

RE: Harley DLC
It was cool, though you can't freeroam with Robin, and I thought Harley's voice was pretty shrill at times.

tl;dr
Everything was improved upon, 10/10, GOTY, etc.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham City- Game of the Year Edition
Not as atmospheric as Arkham Asylum

Don't be irritated by the 3 hours. I played it at least two times when it came out.

In the following text, I'll be comparing it to Arkham Asylum a lot, so excuse me, if you haven't played it yet.
First thing that got me when I started Arkham City were the graphics, definitely better than those in Arkham Asylum. And also the nice cutscene right at the beginning. Then I started playing it. It was and still is the exact same game, according to the gameplay. Only the story and setting are different, alas both above average. I enjoyed playing both, as I have loved Batman ever since I was a small kid. But I liked Arkham Asylum a lot more. It had this dark, gritty tone which Arkham City lacks most of the time. And it also had these crazy hallucinatory Scarecrow- missions. Ah, and also highly memorable, the moment when you thought the game had broken. To me, Arkham Asylum will always be the definitive Batman game. It may not have a world as open as in Arkham City, it may not be as long, but it is atmospheric as f**k.

Still, I give Arkham City
8/10
enjoy it

reviewText:
Arkham City is sprawling with beauty in the details. The combat system is obviously similar to Asylum, but with a little more kick in it. The story is what is amazing here though. The writing in Arkham City and character development is even more embraced than the Nolan films.

You are Batman (obviously), well you actually start as Bruce Wayne getting captured and sent to Arkham City for being opposed to TYGER, since AC is currently controlled by criminals as all this stuff has happened. But you get your gear soon after and the show begins.

First of all, the city is gorgeous, stunning, beautiful, even though the only time is night time. You can glide around and climb all over the place, the free roam is simply riveting. I couldn't have enjoyed a Batman game more than ever.

The plot is intricate, but essentially, it becomes known that Joker is dying from an illness from the Titan formula. You investigate and do a bunch of crime fighting while running into various foes........there are enemies everywhere, just put it like that.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Batman Arkham City takes the incredibly strong foundation created in Arkham Asylum and builds on it a magnificent skyscraper. Everything that made the original game a great experience has been expanded and improved upon, thus making this game one of the best action adventure games you could ever spend your time playing.

The freeflow combat system that was so satisfying the first time around has been majorly upgraded and now features an impressive amount of ways to stun and cripple whoever dares to stand in your way. Batman's collection of gadgets has also been expanded, with each one having applications in combat and puzzle-solving scenarios. Predator encounters have also seen a boost in excitement as there are now a more ways to takedown your foes, but also more ways to be caught by them. The addition of more playable characters is also a great benefit, as each one plays slightly differently, yet consistently satisfyingly.

You will also find yourself fighting a larger variety enemies this time around too, as the game introduces deadlier foes like snipers, armored goons, and blade wielding ninjas. And even more exciting is the larger variety of super villains that you'll find yourself at odds, and sometimes evens, with. A large portion of Batman's rogues gallery is on display here and the ways in which you'll face these enemies are as varied as they thrilling. Sometimes there will be a complex and intense battle that must be fought with hard fists, while other times a sharp detective's mind and keen puzzle-solving skills will be needed.

The most obvious expansion to the game is of course its world design. Whereas Arkham Asylum saw you making your way through the interesting and somewhat linear titular location, Arkham City sees you gliding through the snow covered streets of Gotham City itself, or at least a decent portion of it. It is amazingly detailed and diverse in its depiction and thanks to all the riddles that need solving, those who wish to explore it will be rewarded with interesting stories that give each location, as well as the entire game's story, an impressive amount of context.

And when speaking about the story I wish to say is that this one's is excellent. It starts with a flawless beginning that doesn't directly follow Arkham Asylum's ending, but provides enough information that you feel as though it almost does. This level of excellence then continues all the way through to the end of the main story, finishes off with quite the show. The characters, from the good to the bad, are each compelling in their own right and even though it's satisfying to be victorious over them, it's usually a bittersweet victory because your experience with them is over. Throw in the fact that Catwoman has her own separate storyline that weaves in and out of the main one, and you've got a narrative that is varied in its perspective and tone. My only true gripe is that there isn't a concluding story moment that plays out once you've completed every task that you can do. You're just left to free roam the map, wondering what to do with yourself. However there is an epilogue chapter which heavily features Robin, and while its inclusion does help relieve some feelings of story abandonment, it ultimately still leaves you wanting more.

Batman Arkham City is simply put, a major advancement, in almost every way over its predecessor. Almost every functioning part of this game has been improved from the previous Arkham game, and it is undeniably apparent. It is also obvious that huge amount of hard work and reverence for the Dark Knight that went it to creating this game. And in total, I truly believe it to be a work of interactive art.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If there's one thing that bugs me about modern day open world games, it's that an hour is not a long time to spend playing. It could take an hour just to clean out your inventory or work out what upgrades you want to make to your character and so it makes it hard for me to get into these games from the start.

Batman: Arkham City doesn't suffer these problems and while the open world is small compared with 2016's standards it holds up well design wise and is filled with things to do if you want to stray away from the main story. In an hour you could meet and take down a new adversary, complete a good portion of the main story, complete a good few side quests, find and solve plenty of riddler trophies/riddles and the list goes on from there.

I will probably never 100% finish this game because that involves tedious hunting and solving of riddles and collectibles but the main story and a lot of the side quests in it are really good and the characters and voice acting are well portrayed in 99% of cases.

If you enjoy batman, superheroes or enjoyed Arkham Asylum and want some more then i definitely recommend this to you! (The Catwoman and Harley Quinn DLC's are also worth it) And the game runs really, really well on modern systems with windows 10!

reviewText:
Batman Arkham City		* 10/10
The old saying about sequels being worse than the first seems less true in these days. In fact Batman Arkham City goes beyond Arkham Asylum.

+++Pros+++- The Story. It Goes On Exactly from where Asylum ended, and it's so well orchestrated, by involving many characters, old and new ones, and giving them their own situations and fitting context. The story is so great, full of Turning points with one of the greatest ends ever possible.
- Gameplay. Absolutely fun, following the style of Asylum, this time we can also fly through the whole city... Absolutely the best.
- Secondary Missions are nice and fun, they have some depth, some story, so you do have a reason to play them. Especially the Riddler, one of the best villain in these games, in my opinion... Seriously (Why so serious? XD)
- Characters. It's amazing how many famous characters are involved in the story: old ones, new ones... And Being a Generic Comic fan And batman reader I admit I didn't know anything About Hugo Strange. This made me read more (and enjoy the game more, somehow)
- Endless References, cameos and homages to batman's and DC's universe
- Those damn riddles are more difficult in this chapter... XD
- Playable Catwoman Sidestory. It wasn't much, but it was a very nice addition that gave some variety to the game.
- Nice Soundtrack

---Cons---- Key Bindings in a pre-Game Window only? in 2012? Seriously? Again? This reminds me of Need For Speed... 3... 1998... and that was for graphic selection (software or 3dfx), the keys were editable ingame... 1998... Ridiculous considering the great results of the game itself.
- Those damn riddles are more difficult in this chapter... XD

reviewText:
*****WALL OF TEXT WARNING*****
The legendary Batman Arkham series continues with Batman: Arkham City.  I haven't played Arkham Asylum, so I can't make a comparison between two.  It wouldn't make sense to compare it to the other Batman game I played, Batman NES by Sunsoft.  The game takes place in Arkham City, a new super prison set up in walled off section of Gotham containing the area where Bruce Wayne's parents were gunned down by Joe Chill.  As Batman you fight to uncover the truth behind the walls of this new super prison.  You can also play at Catwoman during the campaign.  The game features challenge maps where you play as Batman in different skins, such as the Animated Series Batman and Batman Beyond.  You can also play a few different characters.  There is an add-on campaign called Harley Quinn's revenge where you reprise your role as Batman not that long after the events of the main campaign.

The Free Flow" combat system carries on from the previous installment
date: which allows for more dynamic hand to hand combat or Bat vs Gun combat.  As you land consecutive hits the combo meter increases and the more hits you can land without getting hurt or taking too long to get another hit
recommended: the more experience points you get.  You use the experience points to level up your armor for both Batman and Catwoman.  You can also unlock extra gadgets
hoursPlayed: improve your gadgets
voteText: and you can improve your combat skills with special takedowns or moves.  There are other factors that goes into your XP gains.  There are bonuses for using different gadgets during combat
helpfulPercent: such as the Bat-a-rang
votesHelpful: the Batclaw
votesTotal: etc.  There is also an "intimidation bonus" where taking out thugs through stealth and concealment.  Once you get down to the last thug standing or if you are only fighting one thug you are granted a slow-mo take down where you can look at the painful last hit thrown by Batman or Catwoman(the nutshots are painful to watch).  Honestly
votesFunny: the combat can get a little boring but the takedowns are satisfying.  You can counter enemy attacks with default RMB
commentsCount: if you see little blue lines above an enemies head they are about to try to hit you.  You block multiple enemy attacks by pressing the RMB the number of times there are people about to try to hit you.\nThe graphics are fantastic
column16: but there are some glitches
column17: but overall it is pretty well put together.  There are times where you can tell that it was ported
column18: but don't let that fool you
column19: it is still a great game.  The voice acting is superb
column20: the Joker is voiced by Mark Hamill aka Luke Skywalker.  Batman is voiced by Kevin Conroy
column21: the same man behind the Animated Series's Batman.  I never found any dull voice acting
column22: even the minor characters were well done.  The game can last pretty long if you go for the side-quests
column23: especially getting all the Riddler trophies without looking up hints.  Overall
column25: it is a great game once you get past some of the glitches
column26: but for me I never had any problems with it except for some long load times at some points.  This is one of my favorite games of all time."

reviewText:
You can either take out people stealthily (as the game recommends), or 10v1 them (bearing in mind they have guns).

10v1 all the way.

Seriously though, great game and graphics, truly immersive storyline with some very good voice actors. It combines everything you could possibly want in a game, good fighting mechanics, good story, good graphics, puzzle-solving, and most importantly of all, Batman! You don't really have to have played Arkham Asylum to understand the game, so that's an added bonus.

I'm only halfway through the storyline, but I would definitely recommend it already.
