reviewText:
Don't let the hours fool you. I have a lot of hours on the PS3 version i just recently decided to get the PC version. I have to honestly say this is one of the best games I have played in a while. Everything about this game i just love about it. The combat feels great. And I love the story of the Arkham games and this one to me doesnt dissappoint me at all. The pc port of this game feels like a really good port despite the specs i have i still can run this game rather well and still have a wonderful time with it. And like with the other Arkham games the riddler is here and boy are there a lot of stuff to do with especially since this is the Game Of The Year edition.

Now I'm gonna talk about the combat. If you have played either Arkham Asylum or Orgins then the combat will feel the same. Arkham city's combat really feels perfect i can't really find a fault with it. If you have ever played sleeping dogs then this combat will feel the same.

Now about the riddler there are a lot of riddles and riddler trophies to collect since this is the GOTY edition. If you enjoyed getting all of them in Asylum/Origins then you will enjoy getting them here. Now i haven't gotten all of them yet on the PS3 version but i do plan on getting all of them on here.

Ill try to get talk about some of the story. The story begins with Catwomen trying to steal from Two-Face but then gets caught then the game cuts to bruce wayne getting shocked by Hugo Strange then a flashback happens and shows Bruce at the gates of Arkham City's gate saying how Arkham city is destorying the fine city of Gotham and he wants it shut down then he gets captured. Fast forward to bruce getting shocked and hugo strange saying how by the end of the night he will be a hero thanks to protocol 10. Its up to you Batman to figure out what protocol 10 is and shut it down before its too late.

And one last thing the music Oh my god is it amazing. Every track fits what is going on. Buy the soundtrack if you love it. The soundtrack can be found on itunes.

Overall I would give this game a 9/10. It is an amazing game and I feel like everyone should play it if you have the specs for it. And as of this theres a sale for it where its only 5 bucks. Get it while its on sale you will not be disappointed.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A sequel to Batman Arkham Asylum and the second entry to the trilogy, it brought back everything that was succesful in Arkham Asylum, but gives you more with more interesting gadgets, and a big city sandbox to play with it in.

PROS
- The previous combat system is improved, but nothing changed too much, since it was already pretty good as it was before.
- Big variety of enemies on how they will try to take you down, of course, that means you have more tools to take them down. Because you know, you're the Batman. Rich snob.
- A large map is yours to glide around, not much to do, but still a big relief compared to the cramped space that was the Asylum.
- Expanded the detective part of Batman a lot more with a variety of cases that range from homicide to search and rescue.
- Two (or three, depending how you look at it) playable characters! Though its still more heavily focused on Batman, you'll get to play as Catwoman here and there. She's a little forgetable though. My only regret is that they didn't expand the use of Robin a little more than they should have.
- Plot twists! Plenty of plot twists! It solved the previous game's problem of being a little predictable by having multiple side missions with their own little story focusing on some of the villains of the past.

CONS
- Goddammit, Riddler, you still prove to be annoying with your trophy collectibles, but now you come back with some really easy puzzles to solve for his side case.
- A little short for the main story, but this is the type of game that you don't just focus on the main story. Its not really a complaint against it, you should focus on getting the most out of this game, not just the main campaign.
- Post-game story uses a better way to fight bosses that aren't used for the main game. A little unforunate, since it was definitely more interesting to try and stealth takedown a boss than rushing at them announced.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A great sequel to a masterpiece of a game. Batman Arkham City took all the great points from Batman Arkham Asylum and combined them with the concept of an open world game - beautifully. I recommend you to play Batman AA before playing Batman AC to fully enjoy yourself.

Pros:
+ GREAT story, many new and interesting characters are added to this sequel.
+ GREAT gameplay.
+ GREAT fighting system. Free Flow Combat is still implemented beautifully.
+ GREAT array of classic and new gadgets, allowing you to takedown enemies with your own style.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham City GOTY review Batman Arkham City is another great game from Rocksteady studios. While they weren't able to recapture the atmosphere of loneliness, depression and madness of the asylum, it is still a very captivating experience.

Combat
The combat was improved, making the stun less useless and the special finish moves less useless. New enemy types are also a thing in this game, you have your standard henchmen, henchmen armed with guns, knives, stunsticks, henchmen carrying shields and MOTHERF*CKING NINJAS.
The game now has an open world, it is now set in the northen part of Gotham that has been sealed off.

Story
The story is great but feels very short, and even though there are side mission you can do after finishing the main story, they just feel like the devs were lazy and just plopped these in to extend the playtime.
The Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC is welcome addition to the story albeit a bit short. It nicely depicts the characters and the change they went through after Joker's death.

DLC
As stated before, Harley Quinn's Revenge is a great addition to the main storyline, however the rest of the extra content is forgettable at best. Same goes for the challenge maps (I didn't want to make another section for that :P), the over-abundance of them makes them feel very cheap and uninteresting (I personally haven't actually bothered to play most of the maps in City or even Origins).

Overall, Arkham City is a great experience and a (weaker) followup to Arkham Asylum and I strongly recommend playing the games in chronological order as it helps to understand the story.

reviewText:
COMPLETED 100%


Decent game with the same excellent gameplay mechanics. Story however is pretty inconsistent; like how the heck did Batman keep up with his same performance despite being infected ill for 90% of the game? The whole main story isn't that long, in fact, it's pretty darn short if you just ignored all the riddler trophies and side missions.
Combat system is quite improved from Asylum but it becomes easy as pie once you master it.
Arkham City is mostly cramped and tiny in size but does offer many incentives to explore (mostly riddler stuff). What's amazing is how the game is completely flawless from glitches/bugs throughout my entire playthrough. Real neat work.

reviewText: Nagyon jó játék volt. A sztori érdekes volt, végig fenntartotta a figyelmet, voltak benne különösen jó pillanatok. A szereplők is nagyon jók voltak, a szinkronhangok is tetszettek. El lettek találva a játékbeli elemek. Jó ötletem tartom, hogy nem csak Batman-nel kellett játszani a játék során. A harcrendszer, a különféle újabb, és újabb ellenféltípusok is nagyon tetszettek. Egy-egy harcban eléggé meg lehetett izzadni, főleg, hogy egyszerre 3-4-5 fajta ellenséggel is kellett harcolni, és mind ellen más-más technikát kellett alkalmazni. A skillrendszer is tetszett, jó volt fejlesztgetni Batman képességeit, a kütyüim képességét, vagy akár Macskanőt. A Rébuszokkal is elvoltam, bár volt, amit nem tudtam megcsinálni, nem is kevés. A bossfight-ok különösképp jók voltak, bár azok nem voltak annyira nehezek, viszont annál inkább lehetett izgulni, hogy le tudjuk győzni az adott ellenfelet. Többször előfordult, hogy elakadtam, és hosszú ideig nem jöttem rá, hogy most mi a fenét is kellene csinálnom, de ez csak a játék mellett áll, ettől lesz egy Batman játék igazi Batman játék. Hisz mint tudjuk, ő a világ legnagyobb nyomozója, és nem csak egy agyatlan darálógép, így az Asylum-ból már megszokott környezeti puzzle-kből sem volt hiány -- már önmagában az a 400 Rébusz kihívás is nagyon sok agyalást, és gondolkodást követel, és ezt nagyon pozitív értelemben mondom. Tehát az egész játék a tetejétől a talpáig teljesen kiváló volt. Mindenkinek ajánlom a játékot, aki szereti Batman-t, esetleg csak szeretne egy jó sztorival rendelkező, játszásra érdemes játékkal foglalkozni. Azok is nyugodtan játszhatnak vele, akik az előző részt kihagyták. A játék nem túl hosszú, de rengeteg tartalom van benne, ha akarunk eltölthetünk 30-40 órát is, mire mindent megcsinálunk benne. Megérte végigjátszani! Kíváncsian várom az Origins-t, valószínűleg azt is elkezdem a közeljövőben.

reviewText:
You enter a room full of henchmen guarding a certain supervillain's gear from Batman's rogue gallery. By activating detective mode you see that there are 8 in total, with 2 armed and a hostage. One of them also has a thermal scanner attached. You slowly creep from a vantage point and begin a silent takedown. Once he is unconcious a beeping sound occurs. Suddenly everyone in the room is alerted to your presence and you grapple to a vantage point to re-assess the situation. You drop down and hide under a grate before perfoming a takedown that finishes with a loud thud. The remaning six run down the stairs and approach you. You hide behind a weak wooden wall that you have sprayed explosive gel on before imploding it onto the first man that approaches. They start shooting at you and you throw batarangs at three of them before dropping a smoke pellet. Activating detective mode you calmly batclaw one of the henchmen outside the smoke towards you, knocking him unconcious. You take down one more before grappling up to another vantage point.

Panicking and with his heart rate rising one guy takes the hostage and threatens to kill him. Another runs up and starts shooting down one vantage point, shouting and saying you won't be able to use it. The third man runs under your vantage point and uses his thermal scanner. However because of your anti-heat detection upgrade he doesn't detect you as you stand perfectly still. You then drop down and leave him hanging from the gargoyle you were perched on as he screams. The others rush over and you use you disrupter to jam the armed guy's weapon. You then throw a freeze grenade at the first guy rooting him in place before flying up to a vantage point.

The guy with a gun becomes shaky as his weapon is no longer working and he has lost sight of you as you have quickly moved from vantage point to vantage point. As he moves under you you drop down on him and knock him out before running to the frozen guy and finishing him with an ice takedown. Batman then proceeds to clean and brush his wristguards very casually.

This is just one tiny morsel of an amazing open-world game. Buy it and play through the rest.

reviewText:
First game was my absolute favorite game to come out in years when it arrived, until I purchased Arkham City. Bigger, Prettier, and still retains that feeling of being a love letter to fans of The Dark Knight (hallowed be his name). If there's any series out there that pays more respect and courtesy to it's source materials and said source's fans it's probably The Witcher series, but this is a wickedly close second.

If you love open-world brawlers, platformers, modern 3ps metroidvanias, and The Bat, you owe it to yourself to play this game, and play it till there ain't nothin left.

NOTE: I know I only have 10ish hours of playtime recorded as of posting this, but I logged many many more hours on my faithful Xbox 360, which I dumped for a PC.

reviewText:
If you enjoy Batman, this game is for you.
It's pretty obvious that this game is awesome, because it allows to be BATMAN.

The graphics are pretty good in this game, story is somewhat lacking at times, but nothing that will make you hate the game.
Gameplaywise the combat system is fun and also repetitive, but for some reason it doesn't stop being fun while being repetitive.
If you already are a Batman fan, you will love the fact that a lot of villains from the movies and comics are here.
You get to see all the three main villains from TDK trilogy (Ra's al Ghul, Joker, Bane), and a lot of more comic villains.
The stealth system is also good, on higher difficulties it will make you think a little about how you are going to approach the situation.
The game also has one of the best boss fights in the game (No spoiler).
Would give this game a solid 8/10

reviewText: Batman: Arkham City the game we all have been waiting for. The idea in which part of Gotham becomes a prison and is put in a game .... yes please. From the start of the game you’re going to be stuck to your screen. In the first sitting I played it for about 6 hours straight without noticing that a little sneak peek before going to bed, turned in to ’’waiting for the sunrise’’. GamePlay has been improved with a faster flight and a few new gadgets in your arsenal but most of GamePlay is familiar. Where I was most overwhelmed was the story which is so rich with good voice acting, lot of action and plot twists. It really keeps you going and playing the game while hours pass by. My favorite part is the side quests which are quite good. They give you an extra content to explore and to see the story behind the lesser known villains. The game is more fun and entertaining than ever before and that doesn't come lightly after his predecessor. I just hope they keep on making great games like this 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Taking to the roof-tops as The Dark Knight in this game is a surprising delight. Gliding through the skies to swoop down on gangs of thugs, solving some of the many side missions, or just playing the actual story campaign - whatever your preference this game will most likely satisfy it (unless you want to be tooling around in a Batmobile, but I'll get to that in a sec)

The combat is well executed and in the style we have come to expect as a result of the Chris Nolan movies and, whilst some may find it repetitive, it has the option of being a straight-up slug fest or a combination of well timed moves. The general opponents range from unarmed thugs to snipers, shield carriers and some in body armour - each of which requires a slightly different approach.

The open-world format gives you the freedom to do things in your own time, breaking up the story with numerous side missions and a staggering number of collectibles" so even when the story is finished there is still plenty to do in Arkham City.

About the aforementioned Batmobile : The close confines and ruined conditions in Arkham City really don't lend themselves to using a vehicle so to be honest it's really not a piece of Lore that I missed. The combination of Gliding and grapple assisted parkour are more than capable of getting you anywhere in the map in pretty good time.

The characterisations are perfect (although this is sadly the last time Mark Hamill will be voicing the Joker) and the scripting is well enough written to let the voice talent really shine. The animations are smooth and fluid
date: even in the midst of combat with multiple opponents.\n\nAs a player
recommended: the only thing I'd suggest is that you get a controller for this game
hoursPlayed: much as I prefer Keyboard and Mouse it is better suited to a handset.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
This game is an incredible improvement on the gameplay front compared to Asylum. The freeflow combat system is incredibly fun, and even better than before thanks to new enemy types, new gadgets, and, most importantly, significantly tightened up controls. People who played the previous game will know all those annoying situations when your punch happens to be just a bit too slow to stop an attack, or a counter not working. That happens extremely rarely now - whenever you break your combo, it is your fault. The predator sections are also more fun now, as the enemy henchmen now use their own gadgets to mess up your strategies, like the detective mode-disrupting jammers and mines, which you can also use against them.

If you haven't played Asylum, well, prepare for one of the best combat systems in a game, ever. I am not overexaggerating. The freeflow combat system is incredibly simple to leare, but fun and has a lot of depth. It is used in fights with up to 40 unarmed or melee-armed henchmen. It's basics are simple: punch, dodge and counter, but add in the whole different layer of gadgets and special combos, and you really feel like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed Batman. The predator sections are a whole different beast: up to 10 armed henchment in open rooms force you to play stealthily, swinging from vantage point to vantage point to take them out one by one. There are a lot of different ways to do this, from a simple takedown from the back to dragging your enemies over railings, blowing up walls and knocking them out with debris, and my personal favourite, disabling their guns, then dropping right in front of them and watching them struggle helplessly as you pummel them into sleep. There are just so many ways to approach an objective, that I can't help but adore these sections.

This game adds a free roaming element to the series, and while it is by no means as developed in full-blown sandboxes, it really ties the game together quite nicely. There are a few sidequests which revolve around you catching various (super)criminals in the titular Arkham City, and they do not feel shoehorned in, although there could certainly be more of them. Simply put, don't buy this game just for the open world, as you will regret it if you do. The riddler trophies and riddles return, and they feel far better thanks to the open world. There is more of them, they give better rewards, and it is easier to find them thanks to the new informant system.

As for the story, well, it is really the only weaker side of this game, at least when compared to Asylum. The linear structure of the last game lent itself far better to the type of story Rocksteady was trying to tell, but it is still by no means bad. Still, the big plot twist at the end is far too easy to spot, and the characters feel weaker than they did in the last game.

The length of the game is around 8 hours, should you just want to complete the main story. However, 100%ing the game will take far more, which should prove really nice for a completionist like me: Besides the aforementioned riddler trophies and sidequests, there is a new game+ with tougher enemies and combat, but you start with all your gadgets, rather than aquiring them over the course of the plot, a 2-3 hour story DLC, and an incredibly large challenge mode.This challenge mode is a bit hit and miss: some people will find it very repetitive. What you need to know is that it can add around 10-20 hours of entertainment, should you choose to complete it.

TL:DR;Chances are, you will really like this game if you liked Arkham Asylum.  If you haven't played it or didn't like Asylum, well, you will probably still like it. All in all, this a really good game and one of my favourite games ever, and I would recommend anyone to try it.

6) Lasts about  6-16 hours depending on your skill level
7) Lots of things to do after completing campaign (interesting side missions)
8) Makes you think (not many games do that)
9) Excellent graphics (not very demanding)
10) You get a satisfaction that you spent your money well

If you're still reading this and you're still not convinced on buying this game let me just say they are 9 out of hundreds of great things about this game, please take my word for this and you will be glad you listened to me.

Graphics 10/10
Sound     10/10
Story       10/10

Overall: 11/10

reviewText:
Follow up to Arkham Asylum, the game that brought Batman to the realm of kickass gaming. In the same vein as its predecessor, Arkham City stylishly blends visual and conceptual elements from the Nolanverse, the Burtonverse, and most of all (and most importantly IMO), the Timmverse.

Pros:

Interesting story, but don't think that just because many of The Animated Series voice actors are involved that this is part of the TAS continuity. Many liberties were taken, but it all plays out pretty well, and pays enough homage to the DCAU to keep us 1990s Saturday Morning Cartoon kids pleased.

An excellent arsenal of familiar and loveable characters.

Amazing voice acting (of course). This is sadly, Mark Hamill's final outing as The Joker, ending his reign as one of the greatest and most iconic Joker portrayals in history, in my opinion only slightly behind Heath Ledger in the Number One spot.

Combat that is fluid, easy enough for just about anyone to get used to, and fun enough to keep you wanting more.

Cons:

Really terrible third-person navigation. This doesn't affect the main story campaign so much, you can make it work well enough, but for a lot of the quick, tricky maneuvers required for the Extreme Challenge missions it becomes a real Bane. Want to grapple to that vantage point in a hurry? Too bad, you're going to grapple to this ledge with people on it instead. Need to dive over this railing to escape gunfire? Too bad, because Batman can't navigate around this short banister. Environmental circumstances must be JUST RIGHT to perform certain maneuvers, and that is really uncool. Don't expect this Batman to navigate obstacles like a ninja when the action gets intense. He's more like Russell Casse from Independence Day (I'm fly... I'm pilot"). On Extreme Challenge Campaigns
date: this causes controller-chucking rage episodes. /rant\n\nMaybe it's just me
recommended: but the story mode campaign seemed a bit on the short side. I have not yet begun New Game Plus
hoursPlayed: but I definitely finished my first playthrough wishing there was more to it. I think that one contribution to this feeling is the fact that they crammed so many big-name foes that none of them really get enough screentime and a lot of them seem to come and go way too quickly. Take your time
voteText: explore everything
helpfulPercent:
do all the things.

All in all:

I definitely recommend the game

reviewText:
Well I waited too long to play this one for sure! A great sequel to the fantastic first game, Arkham City presents a larger game world, more incredible characters from the Batman lore, a lot of new gadgets and combos/moves, nice graphics, top notch musical score, all this made precious by one of the best control interfaces and combat mechanics ever designed for a third person action game (please buy a gamepad if you don't have one!).
The GOTY edition let's you play also as Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing, a nice short DLC campaign is included and there's also a big bunch of arenas where you can test your combat and stealth skills while trying to rank up more points as possible (and that is addictive I can assure you).
Maybe the campaign story is a bit weaker than its prequel's and game fundamentals are basically the same all other from the previous title, but Rocksteady has expanded and optimized every positive aspect of the first game, so I think this is indeed the best super hero game on the market, and one of the best action games / beat 'em ups ever created.
Let's see if they will be able to do better and maybe innovate their franchise with the third and final game of this planned trilogy, Arkham Knight is coming in 2015!

reviewText:
For some reason, I never liked Batman. BUT That all changed when I played This Game:
Batman:Arkham City.I decided to look at some gameplay before I bought it.
It tick all the boxes for my favourite genres
Open World (go anywhere)
(I’m)Batman
A lot of gadgets
Kevin Conroy
Mark Hamill
3rd Person
And I was allowed to play it because
It was within my classification range (M)
I had enough Money
I had the platform I was getting it for(PC)
When I got Home I did what anyone would do…
Put it in the Disc Drive of the laptop and Install it. After what seemed like 3 Hours (15 minutes) It had finished installing and, So I booted it up. It asked me to make an account for…The Dreaded…..GFWL(Games For Windows Live). I couldn’t make an account because of some stupid reason. so I panicked for 10 minutes THEN I had a brilliant idea to fix it...Look it up on youtube. I found that way to get around the no saving problem. I finally got to play and immediately I fell in love with the graphics and gameplay.


The Gameplay:
3rd person
Open World
Batman
EPIC GADGETS
Stealthy or Fighting
Detective Case files

Key Features:
Made By a talented team
Perfect Voice Acting
In-Depth story
Many Easter Eggs (secrets)
Engaging gameplay


After I got up to a certain point in said game my disc stopped working and I was HALF WAY THROUGH. But by that time my game save had been deleted several times making me start again.


½ a year later:
I finally got another Copy of a really good site called {STEAM} and it was 75% off so i got the GOTY(Game Of The Year) Edition and I was happy again. BUT I had to start again. My playtime on steam is around 130 hours!! because of the open world there are many sidequests and thing to collect and secrets to find.


The Review:
Batman: Arkham City is a very engaging Batman styled “stealth-beat em up” with an amazing story. Although They tried to pack all the villains they could think of to add in to make it like the mad hatters tea party i still like it.
It is not perfect but it is still pretty amazing.
I really love how you get the feeling of actually being batman (without the raspy voice) Kevin(Batman) and Mark(The Joker) do an amazing job and so do all the other Voice actors.
The thing I really took away from this is: You DON’T have to be Batman to be Batman. 9/10


My favorite moments:
The best boss fight in the game is Mr. Freeze which was very well thought out making you think and making you use all your skills.
The Combat is what you’d expect very well flushed out mechanics and amazing Free Flow(jumping from thug to thug).Gadgets were well implemented too.
Open world makes any game last longer to make you just want to fly around or grapple and punch randomly generated thugs.
The Bugs and Glitches are just plain funny, once i saw a thug spinning rapidly and i walked right through him.
The cutscenes are acted out using motion capture making them look extremely realistic.
Animations of batman are always either crouching walking or leaping.There are amazing animations like when the thugs see you coming they might cower in a corner.

The BAD:
Not having a powerful computer affects cut scenes making the voices look desynced.
Cramming in all the villains possible makes it look messy.
Joker’s sadistic nature make it appropriate for people above the age of 11.
After you complete EVERYTHING there is no reason to come back.
Story is quite short: 9-10 hours for beginners.
Can’t QuickFire Gadgets while flying
No Batmobile
World is quite small
Big Hard Drive Space (17 Gigabytes)

Final thoughts:
In conclusion you should play this game if you like batman or fun games in general.
it only costs around $7.50 on sale and it will keep you coming back for ages.
I am extremely excited about Batman: Arkham Knight coming out early next year (2015) because it has fixed most of the problems that I had with this near perfect game: Possibly a much longer story, you CAN QuickFire gadgets while flying , they added the batmobile and also the open world of Gotham is 5 times larger than this!

Quiz: What was the first episode of the 1960s batman TV show called? ANSWER: Hi-Diddle Riddle. It featured Frank Gorshin as the Riddler and Adam West as Batman. It aired on the 12th of January 1966.

reviewText:
As the follow up to Arkham Asylum there was a lot of expectations for Arkham City, and thankfully the game lives up to just about everything one could expect from a sequel, adding in new features while keeping the same basic design unchanged.

In Arkham City you play as The Batman who as Bruce Wayne is captured and thrown into Arkham City, a city that has been turned into a prison to house all the supervillains and thugs of Gotham, by Hugo Strange who knows Bruce is Batman and wishes to rid the world of him once and for all. It is not long however before he breaks free and gathers his costume, becoming Batman and ready to get to the bottom of what is going on.

Along the way Batman meets a bevy of supervillains, from Two-Face to Penguin to Joker and more, all seemingly at a war with each other within the city and like always it is up to Batman to stop them all, this gives reason for Batman to at times work with some villains for the greater good, least till someones back is turned.

Arkham City plays, for the most part, just like Arkham Asylum but with more gadgets, moves, and now a big open city to run around in, making it much larger in pretty much every way it could be as well as letting you play as Catwoman in the open city, and Robin as well as Nightwing in the Riddler challenge rooms, each with their own medals and achievements to earn.

Combine that with all the downloadable content such as the mini campaign, bonus maps, and all the skins and you got yourself an amazing package with hours on hours of great gameplay that builds on everything Asylum started. I have very few complaints against this game, noticeable ones being that even though there are more Riddler objects to collect, over four hundred in fact, it is one aspect where more content does not always mean better content, but it is a very small complaint to an otherwise fantastic game, if you loved Arkham Asylum there is a very good chance you will adore this game as well.

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying that for me this is not only the best comic book game ever made, but just one of the best in general.
Now that I've got that out, here's my review of Batman: Arkham City

PROS:
-Nicely sized open world map with more than enough enemies to fight.
-One of the smoothest and most fun combat systems in gaming.
-Great looking game for the time it came out.
-I controls really nicely with both gamepad and keyboard & mouse.
-Well written Story.
-The challenge maps are both challenging and fun.
-Great voice talent (e.g. Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, Tara Strong etc.)
-The gliding is incredibly fun.
-The game has great replay value with a challengeing New Game + mode and all of the side quests.
-The game really makes you feel like, and captures the esscence of, Batman.

CONS:
-There are some annoying things about the combat system (e.g. not being able to jump out of a ground takedown leaving you open to attack, having to double tap counter to counter two attacks at once)
-There are quite a few wierd bugs.
-Overly sexualised female characters.

SUMMARY:
As you can tell I couldn't think of too many cons for this game and the good stuff heavily outweighs the bad. I will always recommend this game.
I have purchased this game 3 times (Xbox 360, PC & Wii U) and I don't regret a single one.

reviewText: Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.\n\nThere’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

reviewText:
What can I say about this one? In a nutshell, it's fantastic. If your rig can handle the higher settings, this is still a STUNNING looking game. Combat is fantastic, intuitive, and just plain fun. The story was well worth it to me. You can either blow through the main story in a dozen or less hours, but if you invest in the side missions, riddler challenges, expect to spend a considerable amount of time in Arkham City.

Bigger is not always better. Arkham City is larger in scope than its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, but is modest in size compared to other open world games today. What we do have here is an amazing attention to detail that left me simply staring at the scenery.

The Riddler challenges require some patience. For some, they will seem overwhelming - just keep in mind that like the prior game, not all challenges can be done immediately. Certain upgrades will be required. Once those are, most challenges make sense and are surprisingly addictive to find!

The Ending? Fantastic

The voice acting? Fantastic?

I played this on consoles when it first came out, but in some ways I felt like I was playing for the first time, thanks to the PC setting option - no comparisons. Never played it on PC, then you need to check out the game again!!!

M

reviewText: One of the most engaging games to date. Balancing almost to perfection action and brains, it's the kind of game that kills your social life for a good reason and makes you feel like an orphan after you finish it, but then there are the challenges, as fun as they are hard; the combos are pure magic, but miss a single input and your rank is history. The graphics are good and crisp even in my old Radeon HD 5670. In my new Geforce GTX 760 is so much eye candy, sometimes I could stop playing and just enjoy the visuals.\nAnother thing that makes it so good is how true to the comic book it is; as you play, you can almost imagine a print version of it.\nOf course it's not perfect, Harley Quinn's Revenge's end still feels like something is missing, but considering the medium the story is delivered, it's miles away from being a bad story.

reviewText:
For some reason, I never liked Batman. BUT That all changed when I played This Game:
Batman:Arkham City.I decided to look at some gameplay before I bought it.
It tick all the boxes for my favourite genres
Open World (go anywhere)
(I’m)Batman
A lot of gadgets
Kevin Conroy
Mark Hamill
3rd Person
And I was allowed to play it because
It was within my classification range (M)
I had enough Money
I had the platform I was getting it for(PC)
When I got Home I did what anyone would do…
Put it in the Disc Drive of the laptop and Install it. After what seemed like 3 Hours (15 minutes) It had finished installing and, So I booted it up. It asked me to make an account for…The Dreaded…..GFWL(Games For Windows Live). I couldn’t make an account because of some stupid reason. so I panicked for 10 minutes THEN I had a brilliant idea to fix it...Look it up on youtube. I found that way to get around the no saving problem. I finally got to play and immediately I fell in love with the graphics and gameplay.


The Gameplay:
3rd person
Open World
Batman
EPIC GADGETS
Stealthy or Fighting
Detective Case files

Key Features:
Made By a talented team
Perfect Voice Acting
In-Depth story
Many Easter Eggs (secrets)
Engaging gameplay


After I got up to a certain point in said game my disc stopped working and I was HALF WAY THROUGH. But by that time my game save had been deleted several times making me start again.


½ a year later:
I finally got another Copy of a really good site called {STEAM} and it was 75% off so i got the GOTY(Game Of The Year) Edition and I was happy again. BUT I had to start again. My playtime on steam is around 130 hours!! because of the open world there are many sidequests and thing to collect and secrets to find.


The Review:
Batman: Arkham City is a very engaging Batman styled “stealth-beat em up” with an amazing story. Although They tried to pack all the villains they could think of to add in to make it like the mad hatters tea party i still like it.
It is not perfect but it is still pretty amazing.
I really love how you get the feeling of actually being batman (without the raspy voice) Kevin(Batman) and Mark(The Joker) do an amazing job and so do all the other Voice actors.
The thing I really took away from this is: You DON’T have to be Batman to be Batman. 9/10


My favorite moments:
The best boss fight in the game is Mr. Freeze which was very well thought out making you think and making you use all your skills.
The Combat is what you’d expect very well flushed out mechanics and amazing Free Flow(jumping from thug to thug).Gadgets were well implemented too.
Open world makes any game last longer to make you just want to fly around or grapple and punch randomly generated thugs.
The Bugs and Glitches are just plain funny, once i saw a thug spinning rapidly and i walked right through him.
The cutscenes are acted out using motion capture making them look extremely realistic.
Animations of batman are always either crouching walking or leaping.There are amazing animations like when the thugs see you coming they might cower in a corner.

The BAD:
Not having a powerful computer affects cut scenes making the voices look desynced.
Cramming in all the villains possible makes it look messy.
Joker’s sadistic nature make it appropriate for people above the age of 11.
After you complete EVERYTHING there is no reason to come back.
Story is quite short: 9-10 hours for beginners.
Can’t QuickFire Gadgets while flying
No Batmobile
World is quite small
Big Hard Drive Space (17 Gigabytes)

Final thoughts:
In conclusion you should play this game if you like batman or fun games in general.
it only costs around $7.50 on sale and it will keep you coming back for ages.
I am extremely excited about Batman: Arkham Knight coming out early next year (2015) because it has fixed most of the problems that I had with this near perfect game: Possibly a much longer story, you CAN QuickFire gadgets while flying , they added the batmobile and also the open world of Gotham is 5 times larger than this!

Quiz: What was the first episode of the 1960s batman TV show called? ANSWER: Hi-Diddle Riddle. It featured Frank Gorshin as the Riddler and Adam West as Batman. It aired on the 12th of January 1966.

reviewText: A fantastic sequel to a fantastic game! I would recommend this to anyone who likes stealth-games and beat-'em-ups. It definitely improves on a lot of things from the first game, such as more upgrades and more fun way to take down enemies. I can't decide whether I like the changes made to the detective mode. I feel it is mostly a change made to make things harder, so you're not constantly in detective mode, scanning for enemies. It is now easier for enemies to destroy gargoyles, which means stealth becomes harder. Another improvement is that you get the batclaw, the explosive gel and the cry-something-hacker-device.\nWith the GOTY-edition you get all the DLC, which there is a lot of, for example the Catwoman-pach which lets you play as catwoman from time to time, which makes combat completely different as Catwoman has different combat tools.\nIf this doesn't convince you, just watch the trailer, which is fantastic.

reviewText:
What can I say about this one? In a nutshell, it's fantastic. If your rig can handle the higher settings, this is still a STUNNING looking game. Combat is fantastic, intuitive, and just plain fun. The story was well worth it to me. You can either blow through the main story in a dozen or less hours, but if you invest in the side missions, riddler challenges, expect to spend a considerable amount of time in Arkham City.

Bigger is not always better. Arkham City is larger in scope than its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, but is modest in size compared to other open world games today. What we do have here is an amazing attention to detail that left me simply staring at the scenery.

The Riddler challenges require some patience. For some, they will seem overwhelming - just keep in mind that like the prior game, not all challenges can be done immediately. Certain upgrades will be required. Once those are, most challenges make sense and are surprisingly addictive to find!

The Ending? Fantastic

The voice acting? Fantastic?

I played this on consoles when it first came out, but in some ways I felt like I was playing for the first time, thanks to the PC setting option - no comparisons. Never played it on PC, then you need to check out the game again!!!

M

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying that for me this is not only the best comic book game ever made, but just one of the best in general.
Now that I've got that out, here's my review of Batman: Arkham City

PROS:
-Nicely sized open world map with more than enough enemies to fight.
-One of the smoothest and most fun combat systems in gaming.
-Great looking game for the time it came out.
-I controls really nicely with both gamepad and keyboard & mouse.
-Well written Story.
-The challenge maps are both challenging and fun.
-Great voice talent (e.g. Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, Tara Strong etc.)
-The gliding is incredibly fun.
-The game has great replay value with a challengeing New Game + mode and all of the side quests.
-The game really makes you feel like, and captures the esscence of, Batman.

CONS:
-There are some annoying things about the combat system (e.g. not being able to jump out of a ground takedown leaving you open to attack, having to double tap counter to counter two attacks at once)
-There are quite a few wierd bugs.
-Overly sexualised female characters.

SUMMARY:
As you can tell I couldn't think of too many cons for this game and the good stuff heavily outweighs the bad. I will always recommend this game.
I have purchased this game 3 times (Xbox 360, PC & Wii U) and I don't regret a single one.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
*SPOILERS!*





In many ways not as good as Arkham Asylum. The More open world can become confusing but also seem a little empty as Batman spends most of his time jumpting from rooftop to rooftop or gliding about the city. On the other hand the additional characters gadgets and abilities give this game an edge in that department.
The plot is well done, though within the actual fram of the game missies out the history of Arkham City in any detail (though some can be found secondarily throughout the game) and it leaves it feeling a little detatched from the first.
Catwoman is an interesting addition and incredibly well done, though my own feeling the switch between characters ended up feeling a little jarring and that Catwoman would have been better left as a complete expanson, as her story is minimal.

*SPOILERS END!*

On the whole, if you want a good Batman game, get the first one. if you've played that, get this, but be prepared to dedicate some time to it and not expect the same feeling the first gave so many.

reviewText:
Português abaixo
An amazing sequence for Arkham Asylum, Arkham City manages to keep all the good elements of the first game, but including a vast and incredibly detailed open world. Combat controllers are more instinctive, but you also will have to deal with a greater number of enemies at once; the result is a likewise difficulty level, but with a greater immersion feeling. Is also easier to feel like the Batman during the stealth scenes, since the possibilities of hiding and hunting your enemies one by one were also improved.
I'm really anxious to see what Rocksteady will bring in the third chapter of the series.

------------

Uma sequência fantástica para Arkham Asylum, Arkham City consegue manter todos os bons elementos do primeiro jogo, e ainda incluindo um mundo aberto rico e incrivelmente detalhado. Os controles de combate estão mais instintivos, porém você terá que enfrentar um número maior de inimigos de uma única vez; o resultado é uma dificuldade similar, porém com uma maior capacidade de imersão. Também é mais fácil se sentir como o Batman nas cenas de predador, já que as possibilidades de se esconder e caçar os inimigos um por um foram consideravelmente aprimoradas.
Estou realmente ansioso para ver o que a Rocksteady irá trazer aos jogadores no terceiro e último capíyulo da série.

reviewText:
Well I waited too long to play this one for sure! A great sequel to the fantastic first game, Arkham City presents a larger game world, more incredible characters from the Batman lore, a lot of new gadgets and combos/moves, nice graphics, top notch musical score, all this made precious by one of the best control interfaces and combat mechanics ever designed for a third person action game (please buy a gamepad if you don't have one!).
The GOTY edition let's you play also as Catwoman, Robin and Nightwing, a nice short DLC campaign is included and there's also a big bunch of arenas where you can test your combat and stealth skills while trying to rank up more points as possible (and that is addictive I can assure you).
Maybe the campaign story is a bit weaker than its prequel's and game fundamentals are basically the same all other from the previous title, but Rocksteady has expanded and optimized every positive aspect of the first game, so I think this is indeed the best super hero game on the market, and one of the best action games / beat 'em ups ever created.
Let's see if they will be able to do better and maybe innovate their franchise with the third and final game of this planned trilogy, Arkham Knight is coming in 2015!

reviewText:
Batman Arkham CIty is simply amazing.

The events take place right after the events of Arkham Asylum.Only this time,instead of an Asylum there is a City full of thugs and Supervillains.

Plot :

Professor Hugo Strange,operates Arkham City and he has put there all the thugs and criminals,including famous Supervillains.
Bruce Wayne (a.k.a. Batman) has a press conference talking about the dangers of Arkham City,as well as his request to shut it down.Then,T.Y.G.E.R guards confront Wayne by the order of Hugo Strange and send him to Arkham CIty.
After a short conversation with Strange,Bruce finds a way to escape but eventually gets caught.Then, he fights with several thugs.Then finally,Wayne escapes for good and becomes the Batman.This time,his only goal is to confront Strange and stop Arkham CIty for good.
After a little while of gameplay,Batman encounters Catwoman who is in the hands of Two-Face.After that,Batman analyzes clues leading him to the Church were there are hostages trapped from Jokers Thugs.After he saves them,they tell Batman that Joker is inside a Building inside Arkham CIty.Batman, using his technology tracks down Joker's signal wich leads him to a factory.Batman goes there,but Joker fools him and, with the help of Harley Quinn,poisons Batman.
Batman realizes that he has to find a cure to stop the poisoning.And with a little help from Alfred,his butler,Batman realizes that he has to find his old enemy Mister Freeze,who has the only cure.When Batman finds Freeze,he understands that he cant give him the antidote without blood samples.So,Batman suggest Freeze that he should go find his Mentor,Ra's Al Ghul.Then,Batman find the place were Ra's is.But in order to talk to him,he must pass the Trials of Death.Batman passes them and has a talk with Ra's.Finally after he has his blood sample,Batman returns to Mister Freeze.But saddly,Harley Quinn steals the cure and Batman must find her, in order to repossess the cure.
After his second visit to the factory,Batman falls in the trap of the Joker.But suddenly,Hugo Strange sets in function his deadly project called Protocol 10.But,after Strange does that,the place were he is in, is protected by a special code which is in one of the many helicopters that fly atop of Arkham City.Batman must find the correct helicopter that contains the code in order to apprehend Strange.
Will Batman stop the Joker and fool Strange's plans ? You must play to find out !

Personal Opinion :

I really enjoyed the game.It was the Game of the Year for me as well as one of my favourite games i have ever played.
The graphics are amazing with smooth animations that make the game trully original and beautifull.
It has better graphics than Arkham Asylum and it is generally a very good improvement.During my gameplay,i found only 3 glitches.They were not serious ones as they took place for only 2 seconds,so it is nothing to worry about.
The story is breathtating,including shocking plot twists that will leave you stunned.It has an unusual atmoshpere and ,the main character will look like hell by the end of the game.It is a very nice detail that gives the game a generally nice feeling.
The combat system is the HIGHLIGHT of the game.It is its best aspect.You can take out enemies with face-to-face combat or just by good old stealth.It is very challenging and at the same time fun.In the face-to-face combat you must keep your Hit Streak from stopping.If you do that,you will see Batman take out his enemies one by one with incredibly awesome combat moves.You can also counter enemie's moves and as I mentioned before, with smooth animations, and slow motion at the last hit.While in the Stealth Mode, you must try not to be detected by your enemies and at the same taking them out silently in order not to be spotted.
This game also includes the DLC : Harley Quinns Revenge.As well as the other Outfits for Batman.They are available after you beat the game.The game also contains extra stages were the player tests his combat skills.Both in Stealth and in Open-Combat.Lastly,if youre think you are so good,you can try the Story Mode Plus,were the only difference is that there is no Counter-Hint.

''WARNING''

Harley Quinn's Revenge contains MAJOR SPOILERS from the main story.Play it only after you beat the main game.



I'll rate this game...........9/10    You should definetly give it try.

reviewText:
If you played Arkham Asylum before this you will probably be a little disappointed.

Arkham City's devs chose the safe route and basically recycled everything from Arkham Asylum and put it in this one.They polished the combat/graphics a little but there's not a huge difference.

The game is based in a pretty big city where they tried to implement the ''open world'' feel but I think they didn't really succed.The optional quests are not that interesting and most likely you will ignore them.The city has a lot of secrets and it is fun to explore it,the only problem is the lack of optional quests.With a city like this they could add so many interesting quests but they focused more on the main campaign while still building this amazing city.

The plot in this game is a bit weaker than in the previous game in my opinion but it is still worth following.I feel like the atmosphere of the game is a bit off,while in the first it is top notch.

As I said before,the combat is almost the same with little improvement.

Arkham City is definitely a great game but it is sad that they didn't take any risks and basically took Asylum,polished it a little and added another plot to it.

reviewText: The world is not over-large but big enough that it doesn't feel cramped and detailed enough to convince but not so detailed as to distract. The combat system is precise, full of useful options and endlessly entertaining. The voice acting is positively top-notch. The music is excellent. reviewText: This game is awesome. The storyline is engaging (albeit short), the gameplay is smooth and easy to learn, the graphics are pretty good, and the staggering amount of side missions and game modes ensures that you won't run out of things to do for a very long time. The game is set in a detailed open-world mini city, with little side missions everywhere. There is also a bonus level, an alternate version of the storyline, and challenge maps that require you to beat up thugs by the truckful, along with the delightful predator mode gameplay, which is basically hiding in a high place and swooping in to take out your enemies before they know what hit them. If that wasn't enough, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing are playable characters in various game modes. This is a great game. Get it and you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Follow up to Arkham Asylum, the game that brought Batman to the realm of kickass gaming. In the same vein as its predecessor, Arkham City stylishly blends visual and conceptual elements from the Nolanverse, the Burtonverse, and most of all (and most importantly IMO), the Timmverse.

Pros:

Interesting story, but don't think that just because many of The Animated Series voice actors are involved that this is part of the TAS continuity. Many liberties were taken, but it all plays out pretty well, and pays enough homage to the DCAU to keep us 1990s Saturday Morning Cartoon kids pleased.

An excellent arsenal of familiar and loveable characters.

Amazing voice acting (of course). This is sadly, Mark Hamill's final outing as The Joker, ending his reign as one of the greatest and most iconic Joker portrayals in history, in my opinion only slightly behind Heath Ledger in the Number One spot.

Combat that is fluid, easy enough for just about anyone to get used to, and fun enough to keep you wanting more.

Cons:

Really terrible third-person navigation. This doesn't affect the main story campaign so much, you can make it work well enough, but for a lot of the quick, tricky maneuvers required for the Extreme Challenge missions it becomes a real Bane. Want to grapple to that vantage point in a hurry? Too bad, you're going to grapple to this ledge with people on it instead. Need to dive over this railing to escape gunfire? Too bad, because Batman can't navigate around this short banister. Environmental circumstances must be JUST RIGHT to perform certain maneuvers, and that is really uncool. Don't expect this Batman to navigate obstacles like a ninja when the action gets intense. He's more like Russell Casse from Independence Day (I'm fly... I'm pilot"). On Extreme Challenge Campaigns
date: this causes controller-chucking rage episodes. /rant\n\nMaybe it's just me
recommended: but the story mode campaign seemed a bit on the short side. I have not yet begun New Game Plus
hoursPlayed: but I definitely finished my first playthrough wishing there was more to it. I think that one contribution to this feeling is the fact that they crammed so many big-name foes that none of them really get enough screentime and a lot of them seem to come and go way too quickly. Take your time
voteText: explore everything
helpfulPercent:
do all the things.

All in all:

I definitely recommend the game

column16: and I do plan on playing through the game again

reviewText: Arkham City is a hard game to recommend or pan. There is nothing glaringly wrong with it but it feels like a step down from Asylum. City lacks any truly memorable sequences, like the original’s Killer Croc battle or the Scarecrow bits. Asylum also had a more cohesive plot. Plus, while I like playing with Catwoman, I don’t like being forced to switch between her and Batman during the campaign. It just makes things feel disjointed.\n\nThat being said it looks good, runs great, and there are a ton of gadgets to play with. If you liked Asylum then this offers some more of that gameplay. If you pick it up for $5 or so you’ll probably be satisfied with it, but you won’t love it.

reviewText: One of the most engaging games to date. Balancing almost to perfection action and brains, it's the kind of game that kills your social life for a good reason and makes you feel like an orphan after you finish it, but then there are the challenges, as fun as they are hard; the combos are pure magic, but miss a single input and your rank is history. The graphics are good and crisp even in my old Radeon HD 5670. In my new Geforce GTX 760 is so much eye candy, sometimes I could stop playing and just enjoy the visuals.\nAnother thing that makes it so good is how true to the comic book it is; as you play, you can almost imagine a print version of it.\nOf course it's not perfect, Harley Quinn's Revenge's end still feels like something is missing, but considering the medium the story is delivered, it's miles away from being a bad story.

reviewText:
What can I say that hasn't already been said about this awesome game? You're Batman, Batman! And not only do you play as Batman, but you feel like Batman. Whether leaping from the shadows to takedown your enemies or gliding over the rooftops no other game (besides Arkham Asylum) makes you feel quite like the Caped Crusader.

If you liked Arkham Asylum, you're in for a treat. Everything is bigger, and badder. Combat is more intense, and it's a blast to glide through the enormous Arkham City.

While Arkham City is a monumental achievement for games of this nature, there are a few caveats. As an open world game, players are given the option to explore and complete side missions at their leisure. While this can be fun, the side missions are repetitive, and largely irrelevant to overall plot. To a completionist, this can grind the story to a halt. I would advise going straight for each main story objective before attempting any secondary missions, as the story is fast-paced and worth experiencing.

reviewText: Being a huge batman fan for pretty much all of my life, i had to endure spending hard earned money on shovelware titles portraying my beloved dark knight horribly wrong. then along comes a sleeper studio with a brilliant if simple game engine based purely off attack / defend in any other game this would seem like too easy, but were dealing with batman here. the one super hero with no super powers that isnt afraid to slap superman around if he starts acting the fool (Batman- Hush, graphic novel. Jim Lee/ jeff loeb) so the gameplay fit like it should in arkham asylum. With arkham city rocksteady stepped it up for all playable charachters to handle full rooms of trash with ease. i completed the main story in just under 10 hours. but then i began to close out the side quests and have happily sank another 30+ into those the riddler puzzles are great and actually make you think instead of the pull grate/ find trophy formula from the first game, they may have mis-stepped with origins and the jury is still out on his new one. but as it stands Batman arkham city stands tall as one of the best games ever put to code.

reviewText:
The best in the sereis

This is the secound instalment in the Arkham sereies, and this is truely the most eventfull of the games I have palyed.

The overall gameplay is like the first game in the sereis, but it have been inproved, and perfected. The fighting part of the game, is made by using the mouse to navigate whitch charecter you want to attack, you use the left mouse button to attack and the right to counter, you can also use the middle to confuse. Along the way the enemeys get harder, and get new equpment, and new tacktics must be used to deafeat them.

There is also the stealth element, where Batman must take down a room with armed thugs in order to continue or save someone. Here you must plan your attacks and be paistent in order to succed.

There are so many small details in this game, and I really love how many mini games and challenges, there are. You can take challenges in fighting and stealth, and use diffrent charecters such as catwomen, there is also a playable charecter in the story mode, nightwing and robin. Furthermore, in the main game Zaez is on the run, the Riddler is kisnapping people and putting up his throphies and riddles to find again. The Mad Hatter is runnig amok, and so much more.

The story is the best Batman story in a long time. The story takes palce after the events of Arkham Asylum, where the Joker have become sick becouse of the titan serum he took, meanwhile Bruce Wayne is sent to the new jail city Arham City, and here we find out that Hugo Strange now knows, who Batman really is. This makes the plot more interesting, and it only get`s more tence after the Joker infects Batman with he`s blood.

So now Batman needs to find a cure and defeat Hugo Strange, in order to keep he`s identety hidden.

Since this is a prison city, we meet many other charecters, such as the Penguine, Mister Frezze, Solomon Grundy, Clayface and even Ras al` Ghoul. Every single charecter is well made, and really memerable. Along the way, you can also find informatiomn about the charecters, inside Arkham city, this only adds more depth to the charecters and I love it.

The ending is worth talking about, and this is also the part where I talk about the DLC mission from the game, if you don`t want the ending spolied, don`t read untill you see the spoiler over part.

-----------spoilers------------
In this game, the Joker dies, this is a shock to anyone who played this game, and it is truely a fantastic ending. It is clear that Batman will be scared by this event, since the Joker and Batman, have a conection deep down, every fan of the seires knows about. The Joker needs Batman and the other way around, but this put the nail in the coffin and made a climactic ending, that will be remembered by me.

This leads to the events after the attack on Arkham, and guees who`s gone mad? Well of couse it`s Harly Quen. Since the Joker died, she have kidnapped police officers, and turned prttey goth. We also find out that Batman have been kidnapped, and that Harly Quen thought she was pragnent with Jokers child, whitch only made her even more mad. It is up to Robin to save the day in this DLC, and it is a nice change since you have played as Batman all day in the main game.

------------spoilers over----------

Overall this game is really well designed and it is a fantastic story, that have twist and turns along the way, plus fantasitc sceneory, that only will make you love the game even more, thumps up. 8 out of 10

reviewText:
I'm ashamed to admit that this game was my first Batman experience. I'd never been interested enough to watch any of the movies or read the comic books, so I had no prior knowledge beyond Batman being a guy in a batsuit. Even so, I really enjoyed this game.

Gotham City is absolutely beautiful, and jumping/gliding from building to building never gets old. The game is also filled with interesting characters – allies and villains alike. There are plenty of familiar faces for people who know the franchise, but they were convincing enough for me to like them based on the game alone.

Add to that some interesting game mechanics and boss fights (a direct approach will not always work) and an engaging storyline, and I see no reason for people not to play this game. Even if like me, you have no prior interest in the franchise – Arkham City just might surprise you.

reviewText:
Batman Arkham City to me was the best video game released during the 7th console generation (2005-2014). Where ever you go trying to do the main story, Arkham City leads you off the trail to do side missions, investigate puzzles and beat the tar out of thugs. You can do various objectives in different order, it's non-linear. Unfortunately you can't solve every Riddler puzzle until you get the last equipment including the line launcher and freeze blast, but don't get hung up on that. I love being able to fly around Gotham with the grapnel boost, following custom way points or deviating from them to spontaneously do something else without getting lost. Top notch voice acting for Batman, Joker and Harley. The Batman villain roster is impressive. I didn't think much of Batman Arkham Asylum, the claustrophobic setting was limited, but was consistent to the story at least.  It's the perfect sequel. Newgame+ and the hard difficulty proves replay ability. The point in the story where Batman is forced to complete the demon trials was where I became the most engaged.

If you grew up watching the Tim Burtom Batman movies, including Forever and the Warner Brother animated series, you gotta play this. It's the best representation of Batman in a video game.

5/5


Here is a list of my favorite games released during the 7th generation of consoles. Honorable mentions to Dead Rising 2 Off The Record, Skyrim, Portal 2 , Call Of Duty Black Ops and Super Mario Galaxy.


1. Batman Arkham City (Best flow of navigation and mission activity)
2. Fallout New Vegas (Balances FO3 for more challenge and variety)
3. Bioshock 1 (Defines FPS 1P)
4. Call Of Duty 4 (Defines FPS Multiplayer)
5. Super Smash Brothers Brawl (Reason to get a Wii)

reviewText:
If you played Arkham Asylum before this you will probably be a little disappointed.

Arkham City's devs chose the safe route and basically recycled everything from Arkham Asylum and put it in this one.They polished the combat/graphics a little but there's not a huge difference.

The game is based in a pretty big city where they tried to implement the ''open world'' feel but I think they didn't really succed.The optional quests are not that interesting and most likely you will ignore them.The city has a lot of secrets and it is fun to explore it,the only problem is the lack of optional quests.With a city like this they could add so many interesting quests but they focused more on the main campaign while still building this amazing city.

The plot in this game is a bit weaker than in the previous game in my opinion but it is still worth following.I feel like the atmosphere of the game is a bit off,while in the first it is top notch.

As I said before,the combat is almost the same with little improvement.

Arkham City is definitely a great game but it is sad that they didn't take any risks and basically took Asylum,polished it a little and added another plot to it.

reviewText: The Game of the Year Edition of Batman: Arkham City packages new gameplay content, seven maps, three playable characters, and 12 skins beyond the original retail release. Also included is the exciting epilogue, Harley Quinn's Revenge -- in this mission, players are sent back into Arkham City to face their final challenge as they interchange between playing as both Batman and Robin. Utilize each of the characters' unique combat and investigative skills to uncover Harley's vengeful plan and shut the gates on the urban mega-prison forever. In addition to experiencing a new storyline, fans can explore new environments and face-off against Harley's all new gang of thugs.

reviewText: This is my 5th favorite game of all time (my other 4 being Sly's 1 and 2, jak and daxter, and jak II). I love this game so much. The fact that there was a big ol' city full of thugs and croneys, Riddler Trophies, and cool locations to explore made this game the most amazing pc game, like, ever. reviewText: Possibly the greatest action adventure game of this (past) generation. That generic genre descriptor really does apply for all the Arkham games though: there’s a lot of action, and you constantly feel like you’re on an adventure. Rocksteady capitalizes on the foundations of Asylum and takes the series along for a ride on the open-world bandwagon; however, they do so in a way that makes their AAA competitors simply look dull and slow. There’s a great feeling of speed and environmental mastery as you use your grapple and cape, upgraded here as a slingshot mechanism that hurls you into the air before bobbing down to maintain lift. Gadgets are now incorporated into your combat repetoire; A-list villains are actually given their due with some impressive boss encounters; the Catwoman chapter is short but immensely fun; environmental puzzles are more complex while the Riddler challenges are compulsively fun to track down and complete. You want to know how to make your collectathon mini games fun? Make them inherently fun, not because they reward a shiny or an achievement or feed your OCD (although all those are legit reasons). 'City' is packed with fun stuff to do.\n\nThere’s just more of Arkham here: more characters, an expanded moveset, bigger and more diverse environments, more DC universe shoutouts and fanbait (the terrible Harley Quinn DLC is one such tease). It’s the ‘Batman Returns’ of the franchise: a louder and campier sequel that raises the fun quotient significantly, even if it comes at the cost of some narrative and design tightness.

reviewText:
Português abaixo
An amazing sequence for Arkham Asylum, Arkham City manages to keep all the good elements of the first game, but including a vast and incredibly detailed open world. Combat controllers are more instinctive, but you also will have to deal with a greater number of enemies at once; the result is a likewise difficulty level, but with a greater immersion feeling. Is also easier to feel like the Batman during the stealth scenes, since the possibilities of hiding and hunting your enemies one by one were also improved.
I'm really anxious to see what Rocksteady will bring in the third chapter of the series.

------------

Uma sequência fantástica para Arkham Asylum, Arkham City consegue manter todos os bons elementos do primeiro jogo, e ainda incluindo um mundo aberto rico e incrivelmente detalhado. Os controles de combate estão mais instintivos, porém você terá que enfrentar um número maior de inimigos de uma única vez; o resultado é uma dificuldade similar, porém com uma maior capacidade de imersão. Também é mais fácil se sentir como o Batman nas cenas de predador, já que as possibilidades de se esconder e caçar os inimigos um por um foram consideravelmente aprimoradas.
Estou realmente ansioso para ver o que a Rocksteady irá trazer aos jogadores no terceiro e último capíyulo da série.

reviewText:
If you told me 5+ years ago that a lesser-known studio under a massive publisher is making a triple-A comicbook hero game adaptation, I'd be a cynic.

2011, Batman:Arkham City was released, the sequel to the acclaimed Batman:Arkham Asylum developed by Rocksteady studios. While AA managed to exceed the expectations of cynics like me, being a really polished and solid game in itself, AC rose way up higher, being one of the most amazing games in recent memory. Or at least for me personally.

Arkham City, in essence, is Arkham Asylum with a massive open world, slightly better animations (e.g. no more cretins holding their heads when they're defeated, regardless of where you actually hurt them) and more polishes around its edges, It manages to keep the fantastic, fluid combat, excellent level design, atmospheric setting, incredible narrative and oh-so perfect voice acting. So much of this review has been said in my previous review of AA.

Combat in AC is satisfying as ever, but now with more awesome animations and more importantly, more gadgets and the introduction of freeflow gadgets. Freeflow gadgets basically allows you to incorporate your gadgets mid-combat more seamlessly which makes the variety of combos way more exciting. With the introduction of more gadgets comes more approaches in combat which plays a huge part in AC and is without a doubt, extremely fun to experiment with different gadgets in different combat situations.

Boss fights in AC are a major improvement from its predecessor. Each boss is almost perfectly depicted as their comicbook counterpart not only in terms of presentation, but also their method of combat. Bottom line, boss encounters are extremely fun and at times challenging, although some bosses rely alot on button mashing.

Stealth in AA relied a lot on the game's excellent level design and combat/gadgetry to a certain extent (ignoring the clumsy AI). AC manages to yet again, excel in the series' stealth aspect with even more incredible level designs and as said earlier, more gadgets which also are incorporable for stealthy approaches. If you are a fan of stealth games, I recommend playing the game on hard because more often than not when you have a multiple gun-armed men encounter, you are forced to approach them extremely stealthily as guns kill you fairly quick. IMO, stealth on hard in Arkham City is feels just as or even more rewarding than combat.

Talking about stealth, it is almost unignorable to talk about the clumsy AI. Whilst enemies patroling/covering area are sometimes very tight and challenging, it sometimes fails to notice you in obvious positions of their line of sight and I am also convinced they never look behind or above them (unless theyre using thermo). This most definitely needs work.

Presentation of the game is without a doubt a massive eye (and ear) candy. The world is grim, dark and quite large, managing to retain the gothic atmosphere of AA once again. AC manages to have an ungeneric world due to being able to not to use generic buildings or placing alike buildings very close to each other. Rocksteady manages to put a lot of easter eggs in the world pretty well with references to the comic book stories in the form of riddler challenges and sidemissions. There's one easter egg where if you go to crime alley within the game which really generates a ton of feels (personally), if you are getting this game, do not forget to check it out, this shows the amount of effort the devs put into the game.

The music is not only extremely good as well, but its placement within each scene is perfection, definitely worth checking out the soundtrack itself.

Voice acting, oh my god, Mark Hamill nails it down the ground yet again with his portrayal of Joker, alongside Kevin Conroy, Tara Strong and every other villain as well being quite possibly one of the best voice-acting crew in the history of gaming. This helps build a spot-on portrayal of each character which is already presented extremely well with each of their character models and great costume design.

Story-wise, a lot of reviews I've read mentions that AC isn's as strong as AA but I say otherwise. While I do agree some villains felt rather shoehorned into the story after much thought, my initial playthrough almost ignores this fact due to the game's undeniably spectacular narrative. AC's narrative played out extremely well and felt very much alike a blockbuster movie (perhaps maybe even comparable to Nolan's trilogy) as the scale felt grand as compared to AA. Overall, I felt that the story was pretty much one of the key selling points of the game (again, personally).

Well that pretty much covers all my opinions of the game. I admit I do have abit of a Batboner (ok not that small after all..) but whether or not you are a huge fan of Batman should not be taken to consideration if you are deciding whether or not to buy this game because personally, Batman:Arkham City is one of the best games in recent memory. Treat yourselves well by buying yourselves this incredible piece of entertainment.

Conclusion; a fantastic game with incredibly satisfying combat, rewardingly challenging stealth, a relatively large world with excellent world and level design, great atmosphere of grim ( and yet, epicness of being the caped crusader), perfect sound direction and composition, unforgettable characters with their spot-on impressions/models/costume and triple-A voice acting, great story and a wonderful narrative. Yes, this game is so good i ran out of unique positive reinforcement adjectives to use.

9.5/10 - Brings me wonders how TESV got goty instead of this.

reviewText:
*SPOILERS!*





In many ways not as good as Arkham Asylum. The More open world can become confusing but also seem a little empty as Batman spends most of his time jumpting from rooftop to rooftop or gliding about the city. On the other hand the additional characters gadgets and abilities give this game an edge in that department.
The plot is well done, though within the actual fram of the game missies out the history of Arkham City in any detail (though some can be found secondarily throughout the game) and it leaves it feeling a little detatched from the first.
Catwoman is an interesting addition and incredibly well done, though my own feeling the switch between characters ended up feeling a little jarring and that Catwoman would have been better left as a complete expanson, as her story is minimal.

*SPOILERS END!*

On the whole, if you want a good Batman game, get the first one. if you've played that, get this, but be prepared to dedicate some time to it and not expect the same feeling the first gave so many.

reviewText:
You enter a room full of henchmen guarding a certain supervillain's gear from Batman's rogue gallery. By activating detective mode you see that there are 8 in total, with 2 armed and a hostage. One of them also has a thermal scanner attached. You slowly creep from a vantage point and begin a silent takedown. Once he is unconcious a beeping sound occurs. Suddenly everyone in the room is alerted to your presence and you grapple to a vantage point to re-assess the situation. You drop down and hide under a grate before perfoming a takedown that finishes with a loud thud. The remaning six run down the stairs and approach you. You hide behind a weak wooden wall that you have sprayed explosive gel on before imploding it onto the first man that approaches. They start shooting at you and you throw batarangs at three of them before dropping a smoke pellet. Activating detective mode you calmly batclaw one of the henchmen outside the smoke towards you, knocking him unconcious. You take down one more before grappling up to another vantage point.

Panicking and with his heart rate rising one guy takes the hostage and threatens to kill him. Another runs up and starts shooting down one vantage point, shouting and saying you won't be able to use it. The third man runs under your vantage point and uses his thermal scanner. However because of your anti-heat detection upgrade he doesn't detect you as you stand perfectly still. You then drop down and leave him hanging from the gargoyle you were perched on as he screams. The others rush over and you use you disrupter to jam the armed guy's weapon. You then throw a freeze grenade at the first guy rooting him in place before flying up to a vantage point.

The guy with a gun becomes shaky as his weapon is no longer working and he has lost sight of you as you have quickly moved from vantage point to vantage point. As he moves under you you drop down on him and knock him out before running to the frozen guy and finishing him with an ice takedown. Batman then proceeds to clean and brush his wristguards very casually.

This is just one tiny morsel of an amazing open-world game. Buy it and play through the rest.
