reviewText:
***SPOILER FREE REVIEW OF BATMAN ARKHAM CITY***	1/05/15

So after spending 17-18 hours with Batman Arkham City and completing the main story, I must say that I am blown away. This game is absolutely unbelievable! The story is so rich and motivates you to keep pushing in the story, the gameplay really makes you feel like Batman, and the amount of things to do in the game is staggering. I still have not completed the Catwomen storyline or any other of the DLC included in the GOTY edition of the game (however, I plan on continuing to play Batman Arkham City so be on the lookout for updated reviews regarding the DLC component of this game). This is strictly a review of the base game of Batman Arkham.

Story: 9.5 out of 10
After completing the main story of the game, my jaw dropped. Everything that led up to the end, the struggle, all concluded in an epic finale that I will not forget for a long time. I am not going to discuss the story for fear of spoiling something, but I must say that the story alone is worth the price of admission. The written script is excellent, and Batman is confronted by a numerous amount of famous rivals. Overall, I enjoyed every minute of the story; sequences with the Joker (just like Arkham Asylum) were definitely a highlight in my book.

Graphics: 9.5 out of 10
The graphics in Batman Arkham City are excellent. The atmosphere is dark, tense, rich with detail, and a feeling of dread overcomes me everytime I play the game (in a good way). However, this does not last long due to the fact that you are Batman! The environments vary greatly in Arkham City. There is a steel mill taken over by the Joker and turned into something resembling a circus act, a police department taken over by Mr. Freeze, a museum occupied by the Penguin, etc. The character models and environment are polished, filled with detail, and provide for a rich Batman experience.

- The only thing I disliked about Batman Arkham City is that the game sometimes stutters when gliding over Arkham City which I imagine has to be streaming issue (this is a well known issue among many PC gamers). However, other than this issue, the game runs great on my R9 290. Maxed out, I average about 160+ fps indoors and 90-120 fps outdoors. Do not let the stuttering issue prevent you from playing this masterpiece - you honestly get use to it. A work-around that I use to fix some stuttering issues is to pan the camera 360 degrees around Batman a few times - this really helps!

Gameplay: 9.8 out of 10
Just like Batman Arkham Asylum, Batman Arkham City is broken into a few gameplay scenarios: stealth, combat, and exploration - Riddler trophies/challenges. Just like the previous game, stealth is one of my favorite parts of this game. As the predator, you hunt down one thug at a time using different tactics such as hanging from gargoyles and performing inverted takedowns, and using a range of different gadgets at your disposal. Overall, the amount of options you have when approaching these scenarios is amazing, and I can totally see myself going back and perfecting my skills in the challenge mode.
Combat is much more dynamic and free-flowing than in Arkham Asylum. You can now counter multiple enemies at one time, there are many more enemy types, and there are now more gadgets that are hotkeyed to use to string together combos. The combat in Batman Arkham City can be as in-depth as you want it to be. Overall, the stealth and combat is turned up to eleven as compared to Arkham Asylum, and the game really makes you feel like Batman!
The game also comes with 12 side missions (I believe that is right?) that has Batman fighting, tracking down, and helping some classic rivals. Challenge rooms return letting you refine your skills in stealth and combat. Also, with the GOTY edition of the game, Catwomen becomes a playable character whose story becomes intertwined with Batman's. Catwomen controls greatly, her fighting style differs greatly from Batman's, and it is a joy playing as her (I personally prefer playing as Batman, but playing as Catwoman is a nice change of pace.)
Lastly, just like Arkham Asylum, Riddler trophies/challenges return in abundance (however this is not a bad thing). Spread out among Arkham City are 440 Riddler trophies/challenges (I have only collected 170). These trophies/challenges really make you scavenge the environment, and provide many more hours of enjoyment to an already fantastic game.

Audio: 10 out of 10
It should come as no surprise that the audio in this game is stellar. The voice acting is the best that I have ever heard in a game; the musical score bring out the perfect emotions at the perfect times. Gadgets sound just as they should, and gliding around Arkham City with wind flowing underneath Batman's wingsuit is excellent. I could not wish for anything better in the audio department of this game!

Conclusion:
I LOVED BATMAN ARKHAM CITY! It is the reason I love playing video games, and why I continue to do so. This game provides a medium to play as Batman, and should not be passed up on. This game does everything right, and is one of the best games that I have played in the past five years (I do not say that lightly). It improves so much upon the great core provided by Batman Arkham Asylum, yet provides so much innovation to keep the game fresh and rewarding. Do yourself a favor, you owe it to yourself to play Batman Arkham City.

Batman Arkham  City		9.7 out of 10

BUY THIS GAME!!!!

After the successful metroidvania style game that was Arkham Asylum, Rocksteady has to really pull something out of the bag for the sequel and Batman: Arkham City does not disappoint.

The combat has been tightened up from the previous game and feels meatier and more responsive. Flying around the open world is great, if a little tedious until you get the grapnel gun. Even collecting all of the open world collectibles is satisfying.

Even with the slightly lacklustre storyline, made just that much better by the tremendous voice acting and plenty of sidequests to keep you occupied really makes Arkham City into the quintessential superhero game.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:

- An open world that's not too big, but not too small
- Large cast of characters and villains
- Improved, tighter combat controls
- Well crafted story from Batman veteran Paul Dini
- Varied enemy types keep you on your toes in both open combat and stealth/predator sections
- Good amount of gadgets and upgrades
- Many challenge maps with four playable characters (Batman, Robin, Catwoman, and Nightwing)

Cons:

- Riddler overkill
- All but two or three side missions are underwhelming/boring
- Traversing the map can be tedious
- Technical issues
- Horrible looking cutscenes
- Catwoman sub-plot is there for gimmick


The Bottom Line:

Anyone progressing from Arkham Asylum to Arkham City will notice a significant improvement over the previous title. Better combat, an open world with interior and exterior locations, and a large cast of characters will all be welcome additions and make the game feel superior to the franchise debut.

However, Arkham City isn't without flaws. The biggest in my book is the absolute over-saturation/overkill of Riddler junk. There are over 400 trophies, riddles, and destructible objects all over the place and with their integration into a side-mission you almost feel obligated to track them all down - something that becomes even MORE of a pain when you come across numerous ones you can't access yet due to your progress in the main story (needing certain gadgets). This annoyance is multiplied then when you have to come back to it later but to do so requires a lengthy journey to their location hampered by areas that were accessible but no longer (forcing you to find a different path) and/or the simple time it takes to get to them.

Arkham City is also still hindered by bugs/glitches and crashes even four years after its intial release, and cutscenes are absolutely terrible looking as they're done at a resolution and detail level that shouldn't even have been the norm" for 2011 consoles. Beyond these things there are plenty of other smaller annoyances that
date: while not severly diminishing the overall experience
recommended: certainly hold the game back from being almost perfect.\n\nIn the end
hoursPlayed:
Arkham City is a fantastic game that every Batman fan has to play. Easily the second best game in the entire franchise it's not one to glance over because of its age.

8 Joker Balloons out of 10


"

reviewText:
By far one of the best games I've ever played.
After the amazing Arkham Asylum Rocksteady published this masterpiece where you are able to explore the whole city of Arkham (not Gotham!). The story itself is a little bit too short but there are a few sidequests so that is okay.

The gameplay is just great. Gliding and grappling is very easy and after a few minutes you are used to it.
Same for the fight system, which ist easy to control but on harder difficults also hard to master perfectly.

Totally recommended if you are a fan of the Batman Series.

reviewText:
[PROS]
- Play as Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing, each featuring unique play styles and gadgets.
- Improved combat engine with more moves and quick gadget commands for Batman and his allies.
- Superb voice acting from Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill in addition to notable voice actors such as Tara Strong and Troy Baker.
- Variety of Side Missions featuring iconic Batman villains.
- Unique boss battles that greatly improve the experiences from the previous installment; Mr. Freeze's battle is especially noteworthy.
- 10+ hours of content just for the story mode.
- 60 to 80+ hours of content to 100% the game (for completionist players).

[CONS]
- Riddler trophies can be frustrating to solve and collect.
- Completing Catwoman's, Robin's, and Nightwing's Riddler Challenges will take a heavy investment of time and energy;
- Each of these characters have limited moves and gadgets compared to Batman which could prove troublesome when earning specific medals.
- Expect 40+ hours to fully 100% the game, possibly more if you are not experienced with the predator maps.

I recommend Batman: Arkham City to fans of the first game and superhero games in general. Many improvements and the complete access to all the skins and characters, and Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC make this the definitive edition of Arkham City. Great game to buy at a discount (around $5)!
